componenttext: We haven't given that, Kevin. We're going from roughly a 12% tax rate last year to mid-teens. So I'll let you just do the math behind that, but we can easily calculate that impact, if you will.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I didn't know if there is any kind of nuances in there. And then just in terms of the continued spending on the compliance side, the 3.5% to 4%, is it the same type of spend and is that independent of the technology spend or is that all wrapped in o
componenttext: Okay. I didn't know if there is any kind of nuances in there. And then just in terms of the continued spending on the compliance side, the 3.5% to 4%, is it the same type of spend and is that independent of the technology spend or is that all wrapped in one?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a similar type of spend. Well over half of the spending is for people cost and we have over 2,000 people on the compliance organization here at Western Union. We obviously have them in various centers around the world. So that's where a lot of t
componenttext: Yes, it's a similar type of spend. Well over half of the spending is for people cost and we have over 2,000 people on the compliance organization here at Western Union. We obviously have them in various centers around the world. So that's where a lot of the spending is, but we're continuing to invest in technology and outside services to optimize our spending there as much as we can, so -- but it is largely the same kind of spending, but just this is a global effort, if you will. So we're going to continue to expand these programs around the world.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Tom McCrohan of CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question is from Tom McCrohan of CLSA.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: What's your expectations this year for total growth in cross-border principal which I think ended the year, constant currency, about 1%?
componenttext: What's your expectations this year for total growth in cross-border principal which I think ended the year, constant currency, about 1%?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, the World Bank has estimated principal growth to be 1% this year, but as we know, that information is more directional than anything else. And as the data continues to come in and get updated, so we'll see where that ultimately ends up. Last ye
componenttext: Yes. Well, the World Bank has estimated principal growth to be 1% this year, but as we know, that information is more directional than anything else. And as the data continues to come in and get updated, so we'll see where that ultimately ends up. Last year, our principal grew by 2% on a constant currency basis and then was down 5% on a reported basis.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can you give us a sense for the proportion of your total cross-border principal that is oil sensitive or emanating from oil-producing countries?
componenttext: And can you give us a sense for the proportion of your total cross-border principal that is oil sensitive or emanating from oil-producing countries?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, if you look at the oil-producing countries in which we operate, it's -- the revenue generated from those countries is in that 10% to 15% range, and it's really a mix story in those oil producing nations. As Hikmet mentioned earlier, the UAE a
componenttext: Yes. I mean, if you look at the oil-producing countries in which we operate, it's -- the revenue generated from those countries is in that 10% to 15% range, and it's really a mix story in those oil producing nations. As Hikmet mentioned earlier, the UAE and Saudi Arabia have continued to thus far, show decent growth. But we have other markets like Angola maybe and others that are having -- and Russia as well, that are just having a challenging time. So it's really a mixed bag and then the broader impacts from lower oil prices in other outbound markets is also a mix story. We have had good growth in some key outbound markets as a result, I think, of just those kinds of situations, so -- but generally, 10% to 15% of revenues is from oil-producing nations.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the trends post he end of the quarter at Saudi Arabia and UAE, were they still similar to what you experienced during the quarter?
componenttext: And the trends post he end of the quarter at Saudi Arabia and UAE, were they still similar to what you experienced during the quarter?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we don't give any inter-quarter information but from the fourth quarter, that's where we saw the state really hit the stage.
componenttext: Well, we don't give any inter-quarter information but from the fourth quarter, that's where we saw the state really hit the stage.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next  question is from Bob Napoli of William Blair.
componenttext: Our next  question is from Bob Napoli of William Blair.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: With your competitors signing a new contract with Wal-Mart, I think that contract -- the old contract excluded Wal-Mart from talking to Western Union, I believe. And this contract, I think, was less exclusive than the prior one. So I just wondered if you
componenttext: With your competitors signing a new contract with Wal-Mart, I think that contract -- the old contract excluded Wal-Mart from talking to Western Union, I believe. And this contract, I think, was less exclusive than the prior one. So I just wondered if you had any -- if there are any thoughts if Western Union was increasingly interested in Wal-Mart, if you think there -- maybe leave it there and get an answer to that question.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, good question but as you know, we don't make any comments on any negotiations or any other specific partnership capabilities as you could imagine, from competitive reasons. And generally, I don't do that. But I just can tell you that I am interested
componenttext: Bob, good question but as you know, we don't make any comments on any negotiations or any other specific partnership capabilities as you could imagine, from competitive reasons. And generally, I don't do that. But I just can tell you that I am interested on any partner to grow out my business. I believe that we will look always to grow our business and -- but it has to be profitable. It has to pay back not for any price and we want to get new customers. We want to get additional customers and we will definitely look in any potential partnership worldwide anywhere.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're not excluded from any of your other partners from working with Wal-Mart, and do you think nonexclusive sends are the way of the future in the U.S.?
componenttext: You're not excluded from any of your other partners from working with Wal-Mart, and do you think nonexclusive sends are the way of the future in the U.S.?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Generally, I would say that I can only speak for my business, the exclusivity generally and the exclusivity has been very stable. And our top 40 agents or 35 agents, they have been exclusive more than 18 years and they -- most of the agents are choosing t
componenttext: Generally, I would say that I can only speak for my business, the exclusivity generally and the exclusivity has been very stable. And our top 40 agents or 35 agents, they have been exclusive more than 18 years and they -- most of the agents are choosing the exclusive because they know they have a quite stable partner, financially stable, good anti-money laundering system, good settlement system, long rent capability, great rent and they can drop money in 200 countries immediately. So the exclusive comes not to count both sides, obviously. And they would like to protect good partnership for a longer time. Then we have also post those [ph] connections, we have IT implementation with our partners. And so I feel for my part of business, quite comfortable on the exclusive.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you're not excluded from working with Wal-Mart from like from Kroger or any of your other partners?
componenttext: And you're not excluded from working with Wal-Mart from like from Kroger or any of your other partners?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't -- I can answer that question, but I guess not, I don't know. I mean, you have to ask that question to the others, not to me.
componenttext: I don't -- I can answer that question, but I guess not, I don't know. I mean, you have to ask that question to the others, not to me.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Raj, you have -- you mentioned a $1 billion of debt coming due in 2016. With credit spreads having widened so much, is there any -- what would be the impact if you were to refinance that debt today on your interest expense?
componenttext: Okay. And Raj, you have -- you mentioned a $1 billion of debt coming due in 2016. With credit spreads having widened so much, is there any -- what would be the impact if you were to refinance that debt today on your interest expense?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Taking everything into account, Bob, where we see interest expense being similar to last year, so potentially higher interest rates for that refinancing, but we have lower overall average debt balance of this year as we paid off some maturities from last
componenttext: Taking everything into account, Bob, where we see interest expense being similar to last year, so potentially higher interest rates for that refinancing, but we have lower overall average debt balance of this year as we paid off some maturities from last year. So those 2 things would largely offset. I would expect to see interest expense similar to last year.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and last question. With your Investor Day coming up and why now for the Investor Day and are you planning on giving any medium to longer-term financial targets as part of your Investor Day?
componenttext: Okay, and last question. With your Investor Day coming up and why now for the Investor Day and are you planning on giving any medium to longer-term financial targets as part of your Investor Day?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, our Investor Day is coming beginning of March and we are very proud about our strategies, what we're going to tell to our shareholders are really how we transform the company, how we get to the new used cases, how we get to the new -- o
componenttext: Well, as you know, our Investor Day is coming beginning of March and we are very proud about our strategies, what we're going to tell to our shareholders are really how we transform the company, how we get to the new used cases, how we get to the new -- our WU Connect platform, how our strength is strong about our retail money transfer business. And we will also like to talk to the uniqueness of the Western Union cross-border engine, cross-border platform. And I think within that environment, we would like to talk to our long-term and all our shareholders, how comfortable we feel about future of the company.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Danyal Hussain of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Danyal Hussain of Morgan Stanley.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just another one on the $50 million tax spend. I know it's early to talk about 2017, but just wanted to get a sense for whether this $50 million is elevated in anyway or whether this is maybe a go forward investment rate for now?
componenttext: Just another one on the $50 million tax spend. I know it's early to talk about 2017, but just wanted to get a sense for whether this $50 million is elevated in anyway or whether this is maybe a go forward investment rate for now?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the $50 million certainly has some one-time costs in there. But again, we're trying to upgrade our platform, so there's also some ongoing cost in that spend. As we add more partners to the mix, especially on the digital side, partners like Viber and
componenttext: Well, the $50 million certainly has some one-time costs in there. But again, we're trying to upgrade our platform, so there's also some ongoing cost in that spend. As we add more partners to the mix, especially on the digital side, partners like Viber and WeChat, as we have more of those, we will continue to invest in the technology area. So too early to say whether it's only one-time in nature or how much of it is one-time in nature. I expect some elevated tax spending to continue but again, that allows us to be faster to market, allows us to be more flexible on how we provide services, and it also allows us to add new kinds of partners to our business which is really why we're doing it.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then not to beat a dead horse in oil, but I'll try to ask the question a different way. So Saudi Arabia, I think they are the second largest send market and they did cut their budget in December. So at this point, are you taking a wait-and-see
componenttext: Got it. And then not to beat a dead horse in oil, but I'll try to ask the question a different way. So Saudi Arabia, I think they are the second largest send market and they did cut their budget in December. So at this point, are you taking a wait-and-see approach for your expectation for 2016, even if you haven't seen any impact yet or are you baking, I guess, some sort of headwind now?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think generally, I am cautious, right, about global economic. It's not Saudi Arabia specific but generally, there is -- the environment didn't get better, it's really very volatile. But once again, I just want to make the point, none of our countri
componenttext: Yes, I think generally, I am cautious, right, about global economic. It's not Saudi Arabia specific but generally, there is -- the environment didn't get better, it's really very volatile. But once again, I just want to make the point, none of our countries from revenue side is bigger -- outside the U.S., bigger than 7%. So we have a really quite balanced environment. I mean, as Raj mentioned earlier, Germany, for instance, produced pretty good outbound numbers again which is obviously engine of Europe and continue to produce that. So I feel comfortable that being that global, having that portfolio, we could respond better than the other companies to the economic challenges.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I could just follow-up on Darrin's earlier question on tax. I know this issue does come up a lot for us, so just wondering if it's possible to provide maybe an example of one of these working capital strategies that you used to repatriat
componenttext: Okay. And then if I could just follow-up on Darrin's earlier question on tax. I know this issue does come up a lot for us, so just wondering if it's possible to provide maybe an example of one of these working capital strategies that you used to repatriate cash without paying for the U.S. commercial tax?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, all I would say is that we move a lot of money around the world annually. We move hundreds of billions of dollars around the world globally on an annual basis, and we have a lot of payment flows between our various companies around the world. So we t
componenttext: Yes, all I would say is that we move a lot of money around the world annually. We move hundreds of billions of dollars around the world globally on an annual basis, and we have a lot of payment flows between our various companies around the world. So we try to optimize those as best as we can. And I am happy to talk more about that offline if you'd like to, but it's really just optimizing the cash flows that we have within the company.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Tim Willi of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question is from Tim Willi of Wells Fargo.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had 2 questions. One, Raj, I missed the full comment but could you just go back over the $25 million of headwind from Argentina? I didn't catch that. I just want to make sure I understand it then I had a follow-up.
componenttext: I had 2 questions. One, Raj, I missed the full comment but could you just go back over the $25 million of headwind from Argentina? I didn't catch that. I just want to make sure I understand it then I had a follow-up.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think you're referring to -- well, we have a -- this year, we have an overall impact from currency and profit of about $100 million. $25 million of that is from the Argentina peso devaluation that took place in December of last year. Another $25 m
componenttext:
Sure. I think you're referring to -- well, we have a -- this year, we have an overall impact from currency and profit of about $100 million. $25 million of that is from the Argentina peso devaluation that took place in December of last year. Another $25 million-plus is from year-over-year changes in hedge gains. So we have hedge gains this year that are less than last year. So last year, we had $78 million in hedge gains. This year, we have around $50 million based on our current rate assumptions, and that's a negative to the margins. And then the remaining piece of it is just overall translations. So the -- we have a revenue impact of $250 million in our top line this year and a $100 million impact to profits, and that combination is a negative to our operating margins this year of around 100 basis points.
[indiscernible] and Argentina is just the translation of our profit is going to translate into to $25 million last year based on the devaluation of the currency.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And my follow-up, going sort of westernunion.com and sort of the global expansion that you seem to be moving on here more aggressively. Is there anything around reallocating marketing budgets or elevated levels of marketing or anything like that,
componenttext: Got you. And my follow-up, going sort of westernunion.com and sort of the global expansion that you seem to be moving on here more aggressively. Is there anything around reallocating marketing budgets or elevated levels of marketing or anything like that, as you really open up this platform that we should think about in terms of operating leverage, whether pros or corns as you roll this out more globally and really try to accelerate it?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, absolutely. I think we are focused on the send countries, major send countries, obviously. The 34 countries which I mentioned earlier are the major send countries. Now we are -- we have almost all European countries. Obviously, now we're sta
componenttext: Yes. I think, absolutely. I think we are focused on the send countries, major send countries, obviously. The 34 countries which I mentioned earlier are the major send countries. Now we are -- we have almost all European countries. Obviously, now we're starting to have our -- we are by the way, in Europe, we are using our bank license there and to expand the westernunion.com. And now, the next step is in Europe, putting promotions and marketing programs there to drive the revenue even stronger which is a good strong -- but the base is still small but growing stronger. And now we recently opened an office in Asia to expand our activities  also, westernunion.com activities to send Asian countries like in Singapore, Hong Kong, but also in Middle East like typical countries in Middle East, outbound countries. And you'll hear coming up, new announcements on that, using our capabilities. And I believe it's really attracting new customer segments. For instance, people who want to send in a different way, don't want to carry cash in a location. And we saw the similar pattern also in Europe. These are additional customers, not one that use retail, but still they want to use Western Union and add additional growth. And that's going to happen, I believe, also in Asia.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So are you comfortable in terms of the P&L impact that there's not any pressure on margins? This will just be reallocating your existing marketing budget to different channels and countries, not anything necessarily incremental on a material level?
componenttext: So are you comfortable in terms of the P&L impact that there's not any pressure on margins? This will just be reallocating your existing marketing budget to different channels and countries, not anything necessarily incremental on a material level?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tim. From a marketing standpoint, we've been spending just under 4% of revenues as a company in the last few years, but we have been reallocating more to the digital areas and that will probably continue, but not affecting the overall budget.And I
componenttext:
Yes, Tim. From a marketing standpoint, we've been spending just under 4% of revenues as a company in the last few years, but we have been reallocating more to the digital areas and that will probably continue, but not affecting the overall budget.
And I think we have time for one more question and I there's 1 more person in the queue.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question today is from Oscar Turner of SunTrust.
componenttext: Our last question today is from Oscar Turner of SunTrust.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you mentioned that overall, you expect C2C pricing trends to remain stable in 2016. I was just wondering if you can provide some general color on the proportion of markets where you're typically able to raise prices versus perhaps those that are more c
componenttext: So you mentioned that overall, you expect C2C pricing trends to remain stable in 2016. I was just wondering if you can provide some general color on the proportion of markets where you're typically able to raise prices versus perhaps those that are more competitive?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have 16,000 corridors that we operate in. So we have a number of different combinations that you could envision, but it's very hard for us to tell you specifically by country. We typically -- in many countries, we're priced above the overall average. I
componenttext: We have 16,000 corridors that we operate in. So we have a number of different combinations that you could envision, but it's very hard for us to tell you specifically by country. We typically -- in many countries, we're priced above the overall average. In other countries, we're priced below. And we also have different channels that we're also utilizing. So in our wu.com business, we actually are priced quite competitively with similar kinds of products. So it really just depends on which quarters you're talking about, which channels and there's a multitude of different combinations that we could be looking at. But in markets where we believe the value proposition is not aligned then we'll take the opportunity to look at that. It could be pricing changes in foreign exchange, it could been in fees. So it's hard for me to tell you a specific area where we do that.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sometimes we increase prices in different bands, current corridors and lower bands, increase or decrease pricing and increase on the higher bands. So it's really a very intelligent price product we have and business. Based on the market environment,
componenttext: Yes, sometimes we increase prices in different bands, current corridors and lower bands, increase or decrease pricing and increase on the higher bands. So it's really a very intelligent price product we have and business. Based on the market environment, we adapt the prices to the customer needs and that's what we do.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second question, you talked a lot about expanding wu.com geographically and then also growing WU Connect. I was just wondering how you guys think about possible cannibalization there or at this point, are they so small that it's not even a
componenttext: Okay. And then second question, you talked a lot about expanding wu.com geographically and then also growing WU Connect. I was just wondering how you guys think about possible cannibalization there or at this point, are they so small that it's not even a concern?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think that -- well, first of all, our wu.com business is growing very, very well. And in 34 markets, we're paying out everywhere -- almost everywhere in the world in cash and then we're delivering money into accounts into more than 50 markets. So
componenttext: Well, we think that -- well, first of all, our wu.com business is growing very, very well. And in 34 markets, we're paying out everywhere -- almost everywhere in the world in cash and then we're delivering money into accounts into more than 50 markets. So that business continues to have a lot of good growth potential, but we also believe that most of -- many of -- much of the WU Connect opportunity is incremental in nature. It's too early to really tell you exactly how that's going to play out, but we believe that that's going to be a good incremental revenue and profit opportunity for Western Union because it's a new kind of customer. They may use us in a different way, different use cases than we have in our core business. So there's -- we just need more time.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Isn't today, Raj, the current customer, 80% of our customers are new to our -- they didn't use...
componenttext: Isn't today, Raj, the current customer, 80% of our customers are new to our -- they didn't use...

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, to westernunion.com. In westernunion.com, we're getting more than 80% of our customers are still new to Western Union overall. So it's -- we think it's largely an incremental opportunity but we'll see. We'll have more experience over the next several
componenttext: Yes, to westernunion.com. In westernunion.com, we're getting more than 80% of our customers are still new to Western Union overall. So it's -- we think it's largely an incremental opportunity but we'll see. We'll have more experience over the next several months and years.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's the bottom of the hour. So thanks, everyone, for joining our call. And we hope you have a good day. Thanks.
componenttext: It's the bottom of the hour. So thanks, everyone, for joining our call. And we hope you have a good day. Thanks.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and welcome to the Western Union Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mike Salop, Senior Vice President of Investor R
componenttext: Good afternoon and welcome to the Western Union Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mike Salop, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Emily. On today's call, Hikmet Ersek, Western Union's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Raj Agrawal, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, will discuss the company's 2015 fourth quarter and full year results and the 201
componenttext:
Thank you, Emily. On today's call, Hikmet Ersek, Western Union's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Raj Agrawal, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, will discuss the company's 2015 fourth quarter and full year results and the 2016 outlook, and then we will take your questions. The slides that accompany this call and webcast can be found at westernunion.com under the Investor Relations tab, and will remain available after the call. Additional operational statistics have been provided in supplemental tables with our press release. 
Today's call is being recorded and our comments include forward-looking statements. Please refer to the cautionary language in the earnings release and in Western Union's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the 2014 Form 10-K, for additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements. During the call, we will discuss some items that do not conform to generally accepted accounting principles. We have reconciled those items to the most comparable GAAP measures on our website, westernunion.com, under the Investor Relations section.
All statements made by the Western Union officers on this call are the property of the Western Union Company and subject to copyright protection. Other than the replay noted in our press release, Western Union has not authorized and disclaims responsibility for any recording, replay or distribution of any transcription of this call.
I would now like to turn the call over to Hikmet Ersek.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good afternoon, everyone. Overall, I am pleased with our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results. We delivered solid earnings despite global economic and geopolitical challenges, which demonstrates the resiliency of our consumers an
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and good afternoon, everyone. Overall, I am pleased with our fourth quarter and full year 2015 results. We delivered solid earnings despite global economic and geopolitical challenges, which demonstrates the resiliency of our consumers and business model. Full year earnings per share increased 5% in 2015 adjusting for our second quarter payment settlement charge and all 3 of our business segments produced relatively good constant currency revenue growth during the year. Consumer-to-Consumer revenues increased 3% in constant currency with slight growth in retail initiated money transfer, boosted by very strong results from digital as Western Union constant currency revenues increased 26% for the year. Western Union Business Solutions constant currency revenue increased 7% and the segment's EBITDA margins improved from 11% to 15%. And consumer bill payments also contributed a strong year with constant currency revenue growing 11%. 
From a macro perspective, while the U.S. market was solid, many other parts of the world experienced slowing economic growth, depreciating currencies or geopolitical instability in 2015, and low oil prices affected several [indiscernible] markets. As a result of many of these factors, we saw significant outbound declines in markets such as Russia, Angola, Greece and Libya. Despite this, transactions and constant currency revenue in our retail money transfer business increased slightly, showing the ongoing importance of cash to consumers around the world, while we continued to drive strong growth from our digital business. Operating margins increased from 20.3% to 20.9%, excluding the charge, and cash flow was strong again with approximately $1.1 billion generated from operating activities and over $800 million returned to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. 
Today, we also announced a 3% increase in our first quarter dividend, which equates to $0.64 per share annually, and we remain committed to consistently returning funds to shareholders. In addition to the financial results, we made important progress in key strategic areas in 2015. Our strategies are designed to leverage our platform and other capabilities to allow us to access more used cases and customer segments for cross-border money movements. 
In 2015 we continued our digital expansion, adding 10 new westernunion.com online transaction sites, which raised our total to 34 countries. We introduced WU Connect, which allows us to offer cross-border money transfer services on third-party platforms, such as social media and messaging companies, among others. We signed our first WU Connect partnership in 2015 with WeChat, a leading Chinese social communication platform and we just announced our second with Viber, a leading mobile messaging app, which will make our money transfer service available to their consumers here in the U.S. 
We are in the process of putting promotional programs in place with both partners, and we believe these offerings will generate incremental revenues over the long term. We also made additional investments in our technology in 2015 to position us for the future and rolled out further compliance and anti-money laundering enhancements. And we expanded our account payout network, which will allow us to target account-driven receivers in the future. This is an important new potential revenue source for Western Union, as funds into accounts make up the largest portion of the cross-border principal pool, and we now have the capability to send to over $1 billion accounts into 50-plus countries.
We will talk more about our strategic initiatives at our Investor's Day in March, but let me turn now to our 2016 outlook. We expect global economic growth to be challenging and currencies to be volatile again in 2016, and we believe we will continue to deal with external challenges and disruptions in various countries. The stronger dollar is also going to affect our reported results. We remain confident, however, that our multichannel business model will deliver solid transaction and constant currency revenue growth this year with strong cash flow and continued returns of funds to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. We anticipate good constant currency growth from westernunion.com and Business Solutions again in 2016 and steady performance from a retail money transfer. 
Over the long term, we believe the unique combination of our strong global brand, our vast network and our cross-border expertise and capabilities give us great opportunities to expand our reach in cross-border money movement, including adding new used cases with our WU Connect and account payout platforms. 
I will now like to turn the call over to Raj to discuss the fourth quarter results and 2016 outlook in more detail.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Hikmet. As I reviewed 2015 financial results, I will focus primarily on the fourth quarter. The similar information for the full year can be found in our press release and the attached financial schedules. Fourth quarter revenues of $1.4 billio
componenttext:
Thank you, Hikmet. As I reviewed 2015 financial results, I will focus primarily on the fourth quarter. The similar information for the full year can be found in our press release and the attached financial schedules. Fourth quarter revenues of $1.4 billion, increased 3% on a constant currency basis compared to the prior year period. Our reported revenues declined 2% due to the impact of the stronger U.S. dollar. The impact of currency translation net of hedge benefits reduced fourth quarter revenue by approximately $74 million compared to the prior year period. 
In the Consumer-to-Consumer segment, revenues increased 2% constant currency and reported revenues declined 3%, while transactions grew 3% in the quarter. C2C constant currency revenue growth was driven by westernunion.com and solid growth from U.S. outbound. In the quarter, total C2C cross-border principal declined 4% or increased 1% constant currency. Principal per transaction was down 6% compared to the prior year period, primarily due to foreign exchange translation as it increased 1% in constant currency terms. The spread between the C2C transaction growth and the revenue decline in the quarter was approximately 6 percentage points, including a negative 5% impact from currency. The impact of net price decreases was 1%, while mix had minimal impact in the quarter overall. The pricing environment remains stable. And our net C2C pricing change for the full year was essentially flat. 
Turning to the regions. Due to the significant fluctuations in foreign exchange rates, I will be referring to constant currency movements as I discuss individual country contributions to the regional results. In the Europe and CIS region, revenue declined 8%, but was flat on a constant currency basis. Transactions increased 1%. In the region, strong revenue growth in Germany was largely offset by continued weakness in Russia. The Greece business improved compared to the third quarter as the market-imposed restrictions were largely lifted, although revenue was still below prior year levels. 
North America revenue was flat or increased 2% on a constant currency basis, while transactions increased 5%. U.S. outbound continue to deliver strong growth in the quarter, driven primarily by sends [ph] to Mexico and Latin America. Our Mexico business again grew faster than the market based on the latest Banco de Mexico data for both the fourth quarter and full year. The domestic money transfer business produced improved trends in the quarter as transactions increased 8% while revenue growth turned positive with a 2% increase. 
In the Middle East and Africa region, revenue declined 5% or 1% constant currency and transactions were down 1%. Similar to the third quarter, declines in Angola and other African countries offset growth in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. In Asia-Pacific, revenue was down 6% or up 1% constant currency, while transactions in the region decreased 5% and continued weakness in the Philippines was partially offset by good growth in Japan and China. Revenue in the Latin America and Caribbean region was down 2% or increased 5% constant currency, while transactions increased 7% in the quarter. The region's constant currency growth was primarily driven by strong inbound business from the U.S. 
Westernunion.com C2C revenue grew 21% in the quarter or 25% constant currency. Westernunion.com transactions increased 28% with U.S. originated online transactions growing 35%. Electronic channels revenue, which includes wu.com, account-based money transfer through bank and mobile money transfer, represented 7% of total company revenue in the quarter. 
I do want to mention that we will be making a slight change to our regional reporting for C2C in the first quarter. Rather than separating the westernunion.com business from the regions, we will begin reporting it within the regional numbers splitting the revenue 50-50 between the send and receive regions. With online transactions right now in 34 countries, we believe this will give a better perspective on total regional performance, while we will still continue to provide the westernunion.com standalone metrics as additional information. 
Turning back to the fourth quarter, in the Consumer-to-Business segment, revenue increased 4% or 9% on a constant currency basis, driven by growth in the Argentina walk-in and U.S. electronic businesses, which is partially offset by declines in U.S. cash walk-in. Business Solutions reported revenues increased 1% or 8% on a constant currency basis. This revenue growth was driven by Europe and led by strong sales of hedging products. The consolidated operating profit margin was 20.4% in the fourth quarter compared to 19.6% in the prior year period. The operating margin benefited from lower expenses and incremental savings related to cost savings initiatives and from foreign exchange hedge gains. These benefits were partially offset by higher technology expense in the quarter. We recorded approximately $21 million of hedge gains on our revenue and profit lines in the current period, up from $9 million of gains in the fourth quarter of 2014. 
Our cost savings initiatives. We had approximately $11 million of expenses in the quarter on actions to drive future cost efficiencies, which compares to approximately $30 million of such expenses in the fourth quarter of 2014. Additionally, prior cost savings initiatives contributed approximately $6 million of incremental savings in the fourth quarter and full year total savings were approximately $32 million. Technology spending and investment increased compared to the prior year as we invested enhancements to our platforms, digital capabilities, settlement systems and data center transformation, all of which will continue in 2016. Compliance expense was approximately 3.5% of revenue in the quarter compared to 3.6% in the prior year period, while the full year compliance expense was 3.6% of revenue. EBITDA margin of 25.4% in the quarter increased from 24.5% in the prior year period. Our tax rate was 10.4%, an increase from 6.1% in last year's fourth quarter, which benefited from various nonrecurring items. 
For the full year, our reported tax rate was 11%. Excluding the impact of the Paymap settlement charges in the second quarter, the full year effective tax rate was 11.8%. Earnings per share in the quarter was flat with last year at $0.42 and increased operating profit and fewer diluted shares outstanding were offset by the increased tax rate. 
The C2C segment operating margin was 24% compared to 23.1% in the prior year period. The C2C operating margin also benefited from lower expenses and incremental savings related to cost savings initiatives and foreign exchange hedge gains, which were partially offset by higher technology expense. The Consumer-to-Business operating margin was 11.9% in the quarter compared to 14.2% in the prior year period. The margin decrease is due to the higher local currency expenses in Argentina, including various inflation adjustments and increased technology expense, which were partially offset by lower expenses and incremental savings from cost initiatives.
Business Solutions reported operating profit of $4 million for the quarter compared to a loss of $5 million in the same period last year. The operating profit improvement was driven by lower expenses and incremental savings from cost initiatives. Depreciation and amortization for Business Solutions was approximately $13 million in both the current and prior year quarters. EBITDA margins for Business Solutions improved to 16.2% compared to 7.6% in the fourth quarter of last year. 
Turning to our cash flow and balance sheet. Cash flow from operating activities was $1.1 billion for the year. Capital expenditures were $60 million for the fourth quarter and $267 million for the year, which equates to just under 5% of revenues. At the end of the quarter, the company had $3.2 billion of debt and cash of $1.3 billion. The company utilized U.S. cash to pay out the $250 million debt maturity during the fourth quarter. As a result, approximately 30% of the cash was held by United States entities as of quarter end. During the quarter, we repurchased approximately 4 million shares for a total of $69 million. Our remaining authorization, which expires in December of 2017, was $712 million at year-end. The outstanding share count at the end of the year was 502 million shares. We also paid $78 million in dividends in the quarter, and we're pleased to announce today the further 3% increase in our quarterly dividend. 
Turning to the 2016 outlook. As Hikmet mentioned, we expect continued steady constant currency results from retail money transfer and good performance from our growth such as westernunion.com. We expect the C2C pricing environment to remain stable with strategic pricing adjustments similar to last year. Our money transfer consumers have been resilient, which has given us a reliable business model and solid earnings and cash flow generation even in some difficult economic time periods. Our outlook does reflect a challenging macroeconomic environment in many parts of the world and negative impact from the stronger dollar relative to 2015 average rates. 
Specifically, we anticipate foreign currency changes and reduced hedge benefits will negatively impact revenues by approximately $250 million and operating profit by approximately $100 million compared to 2015 rates including the impact of hedges. The outlook is primarily based on recent exchange rates with the euro assumed at $1.08. The estimated $100 million profit impact results from just over $25 million of reduced hedge benefits compared to 2015, approximately $25 million related to Argentina and the remainder from translation of profits in various currencies around the world. We expect the benefit of approximately $50 million from foreign exchange currency hedge gains in 2016, but this is down from the $78 million of benefit achieved in 2015. So the year-on-year impact on profit and margins from hedges is negative. 
In Argentina, the peso devalued in late December as new economic policies were implemented, and its value is now more than 30% lower than the average rates for 2015. We have both money transfer and bill payments businesses in Argentina, which represent about 4% of company revenues last year. So the devaluation translates to approximately $100 million of revenue impact and approximately $25 million of operating profit impact. We expect compliance expense in a range of 3.5% to 4%, which is similar to last year. 
The margin outlook also reflects over $50 million of incremental technology expense as we make further investments in our capability. Otherwise, given the challenges from currency, we are managing expenses very tightly. Excluding all impacts from foreign exchange rate movements, the outlook for operating margins in 2016 would be similar to 2015. Achieving our outlook operating margin in 2016 would mark the fourth consecutive year of margins around 20%, with currency contributing to the step up to 21% in 2015 and driving the anticipated step back to approximately 20% this year. 
We have worked hard to stabilize margins over the last few years and what has been a relatively low growth reported revenue environment compared with rising compliance cost, and we are pleased with our progress. We expect the tax rate to increase from 11.8% in 2015, excluding the Paymap charge to mid-teens level in 2016. And we expect the rate to be somewhat higher in the first half of the year than the second. Putting this all together, our initial 2016 outlook calls for low to mid-single-digit constant currency revenue growth with GAAP revenue of approximately 400 basis points lower than the constant currency growth; operating margin of approximately 20%; earnings per share in a range of $1.58 to $1.70 which includes an approximately $0.15 negative impact from foreign exchange and also reflects the impact of higher tax rate; and cash flow from operating activities of approximately $1 billion. 
Similar to last year, the cash flow outlook excludes approximately $100 million of anticipated final tax payments related to IRS agreement, some or all of which may occur in late 2016. We anticipate completing the remaining $712 million of our buyback authorization over the course of 2016 and 2017. And we also plan to issue additional debt to at least partially repay the $1 billion note matured in 2016. 
So to summarize, we were pleased with our -- to deliver our results in 2015 despite a tough environment. We expect to drive stable performance and continued strong cash flow generation and allocation in 2016, while we execute our strategies to drive long-term growth. So with that, operator, we are now ready to take questions.

componenttext: Yes.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess is that what's holding back margin expansion that we would normally see maybe with higher positive revenue growth? Any other puts and takes there, Raj?
componenttext: So I guess is that what's holding back margin expansion that we would normally see maybe with higher positive revenue growth? Any other puts and takes there, Raj?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tien-tsin, the margins would have been about the same as last year without the currency impact. And that includes about a $50 million increase in spend in technology. We are saving other cost during the course of this year and that's why we are able
componenttext: Yes, Tien-tsin, the margins would have been about the same as last year without the currency impact. And that includes about a $50 million increase in spend in technology. We are saving other cost during the course of this year and that's why we are able to keep relatively flat margins. But certainly, if we have not had that kind of an increase in technology, then margins could have been better, but we are investing in our platforms and upgrading our core processing technology, which is a little bit dated, and we think that's the right thing to be doing.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then maybe just as a follow-up, just the M&A appetite or update there. I know there's a lot of news flow in the quarter related to that. What's the latest thinking on M&A?
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then maybe just as a follow-up, just the M&A appetite or update there. I know there's a lot of news flow in the quarter related to that. What's the latest thinking on M&A?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well generally, we always, as I -- like in the past, we look at M&A opportunities. If it looks -- fits up with our strategy, definitely interested in digital environment or mobile environment. In that environment, we're going to continue to look. It has t
componenttext: Well generally, we always, as I -- like in the past, we look at M&A opportunities. If it looks -- fits up with our strategy, definitely interested in digital environment or mobile environment. In that environment, we're going to continue to look. It has to be fit with our strategy and we are very disciplined also on return on M&As. And so we're going to continue to look at that. I mean, I don't plan big M&As but definitely, strategic fit will be within our focus area.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: I just wanted to follow-up on that, Raj, just thinking about the $50 million in incremental technology investment spend. Is there something that's a complete offset to that like the cost-saving initiatives? I don't know if you give a number for that to expect in fiscal year '16, just trying to figure what and if there's anything in detail to offset that incremental to keep margins flat.

componenttext: Okay. And then pricing was down, I think 1% in the fourth quarter but flat for the year. Was there some pricing initiatives taken in the fourth quarter? And then going forward, will pricing be more flat again? Just want to make sure I understand it.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the pricing that you saw in the fourth quarter is nothing out of the ordinary. We still expect low single-digit pricing environment during the course of this year. Earlier in the year, we had some price increases that were offsetting some of the pric
componenttext: Yes, the pricing that you saw in the fourth quarter is nothing out of the ordinary. We still expect low single-digit pricing environment during the course of this year. Earlier in the year, we had some price increases that were offsetting some of the price declines that we had. So it's really just normal course price changes in the market.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Markets look also quite stable, Bryan. So we don't anticipate big pricing investment. The usual ones, but not big ones.
componenttext: Markets look also quite stable, Bryan. So we don't anticipate big pricing investment. The usual ones, but not big ones.

componenttext: We haven't really given a segment breakout. But for the B2B business, we still believe long-term, the opportunities for low double digits on constant currency revenue growth and that's really a long-term objective. We -- and overall, the business we expect to be in the low-to mid-single digit constant currency growth range for the company.

componenttext: I think generally, we'll see very strong growth coming from the digital sense [ph] transaction combined with our network worldwide. That drives really, the growth. Especially now being in 34 countries, it's very strong. And our U.S. business, as you saw, U.S. outbound online business has been very strong. And now we are in 34 countries, we expect long-term also similar growth rates like we have in the U.S. globally, and we're going to continue to expand that one.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jason Kupferberg of Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from Jason Kupferberg of Jefferies.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Cary calling in for Jason. With all the global macro volatility we've seen lately, I was hoping you could provide just some additional color about embedded expectations in 2016 by region. Just kind of if there is any particular region that yo
componenttext: This is Ryan Cary calling in for Jason. With all the global macro volatility we've seen lately, I was hoping you could provide just some additional color about embedded expectations in 2016 by region. Just kind of if there is any particular region that you think could grow, accelerate or any other that are probably going to be particularly hard to hit by some of the headwinds that we've seen.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think generally, our business is quite resilient. Our customers are quite resilient even through '15 economic challenges, the currency volatility, the geopolitical issues. Our business and customers has been very resilient. We did see some impact of our
componenttext: I think generally, our business is quite resilient. Our customers are quite resilient even through '15 economic challenges, the currency volatility, the geopolitical issues. Our business and customers has been very resilient. We did see some impact of our global and geopolitical issues like in Russia, we saw it Angola, we saw it in Greece, in Libya. These outbound countries had some effect to our revenues, but given being in 200 countries, I feel quite comfortable to manage that risk. However, there is a huge geopolitical oil crisis maybe also have impact in the Middle East outbound business long-term. And generally, year-to-date and last year, we saw a quite solid business and our customers are growing. Our growth is also coming from new incremental revenue, new customer segments adding on that with our online business, with our mobile business growing really strong. And these are new customers and it's not cannibalizing our strong retail money transfer business which is resilient.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then looking at the WU Connect platform, I know you would ask a couple partners since launching. I was hoping if you could speak broadly to the feedback you've received from potential partners. And maybe on top of that, how long do you estimate
componenttext: Okay. And then looking at the WU Connect platform, I know you would ask a couple partners since launching. I was hoping if you could speak broadly to the feedback you've received from potential partners. And maybe on top of that, how long do you estimate it will take to start getting some more significant traction within this new channel?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's definitely something that we built over the years, WU Connect which has API connection to our platform. This [ph] platform is basically our multi-settlement currency platform, our compliance platform, our IT platform. We now give the platform,
componenttext: Well, it's definitely something that we built over the years, WU Connect which has API connection to our platform. This [ph] platform is basically our multi-settlement currency platform, our compliance platform, our IT platform. We now give the platform, make it capable for social media and for operators, messaging operators that they have an access and use that. To build that takes years to have license in 200 countries. It's not easy and in the past, we were opening that platform as a kind of a closed platform for our agents. Now we are opening this platform also for new social media. One is WeChat, obviously, and the other one is just announced a week ago, was Viber. And it will take some time. As you know, it takes some time. We have to promote that within the users, within the people who use Viber and WeChat and other social medias. We would like to expand that also to the other social medias, but we've just put programs. One of the recent programs is the Chinese New Year. As you know, that yesterday was Chinese New Year and we started the promotion with WeChat which is a Chinese communication platform, and we'll see the results long-term, definitely incremental results.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Darrin Peller of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is from Darrin Peller of Barclays Capital.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So look, I mean, overall, I think the constant currency trends look fairly stable on most of the businesses. The exceptions I guess, look like they're the markets you called out, just in the last question around the outbound markets being somewhat oil sen
componenttext: So look, I mean, overall, I think the constant currency trends look fairly stable on most of the businesses. The exceptions I guess, look like they're the markets you called out, just in the last question around the outbound markets being somewhat oil sensitive markets, Mid East and Asia, to some extent I guess, Asia maybe a little less. But just give us some color on what your embedded expectations are for those markets. I mean, I guess, they've -- a lot of the companies we see reporting are having pretty big concerns over those economies, obviously. And let me take it a step further in the U.S., there's parts of the U.S. outbound market I know that have historically been somewhat tied to oil-producing areas in the U.S. as well, whether or not that's embedded in your thoughts. So a little color on the expectation for transaction growth in Asia being down 5%, Mid East down 1% and whether that's potentially going to get better or worse in the U.S. also.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Darrin, thank you. That's a good question, actually. I mean, if you look at our business, U.S. has been really very solid. And even in Saudi Arabia and UAE, we saw good transactions. In Germany, we saw good transactions. I mean, I have to be fair, Germany
componenttext: Darrin, thank you. That's a good question, actually. I mean, if you look at our business, U.S. has been really very solid. And even in Saudi Arabia and UAE, we saw good transactions. In Germany, we saw good transactions. I mean, I have to be fair, Germany is not an oil producing country but the numbers have been very solid. Saudi Arabia and Middle East, Gulf countries which has a huge outbound business has been stable. Definitely, there is some risk looking forward on these areas, maybe have some oil prices are down, maybe some economical challenges. But I feel quite confident with our resiliency of our business of our customers. And also, we are starting -- you'll see some announcement, additional announcement to our 34 countries, adding new online capabilities, especially also for Middle East for customers to be able to send not only retail money transfer but also online money transfer. I believe that, that will keep that stable. There is some concerns on the economic challenges. There is -- global environment is not stable, I'm cautious about that, but customers -- don't forget also, none of our countries out of the U.S. are bigger than 7%, Raj, I believe of oil revenue?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: Okay. All right, that's helpful. And then just on the other -- the non-C2C segment, C2B and the business solution segments. I mean, I know generally, FX volatility has been an impactful driver on the business solutions side of the business. Anything that's impacting that there or anything else we should think about from -- given all the volatility macro we're hearing across the board?

componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it's not like '14 or before, like the global trade is growing very strong. There is some -- global trade is not as we would like to see and as you know, our B2B business is dependent on global trade activities. But I have to say that in Europ
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it's not like '14 or before, like the global trade is growing very strong. There is some -- global trade is not as we would like to see and as you know, our B2B business is dependent on global trade activities. But I have to say that in Europe, especially, the B2B business, we are doing pretty well. And of our markets where we are active like U.K. or other markets like France and Continental Europe, Kerry's team has been doing a good job here and growing pretty well. Though there is, Darrin, as you know, there is something, global trade could be impacting our business but currently, I don't see big changes.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just also add, Darrin, that hedging has also helped some of the results there and that activity continues to expand into more markets around the world.
componenttext: I would just also add, Darrin, that hedging has also helped some of the results there and that activity continues to expand into more markets around the world.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That's good to hear. And just last question for me, and I'll turn it back to the queue, is on the tax rate. I know it comes up this year, doing more normalized mid-teens level. I guess, just big picture on that. I mean, I imagine that slowly but surely, move to a high double -- like more closer to 20%, is that the right way to think about it for modeling purposes over the next couple of years?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't speak to your model but for us, we believe that the mid-teens tax rate is something that we would still have for the next couple of years. Obviously, it's dependent on tax law changes and other things that may happen. But based on what we know tod
componenttext: I can't speak to your model but for us, we believe that the mid-teens tax rate is something that we would still have for the next couple of years. Obviously, it's dependent on tax law changes and other things that may happen. But based on what we know today, that's roughly where we see the tax rate. And this year is coming out to be right where we said during the course of last year. We thought we would be back in the mid-teens and we are, and that's what we see for the next couple of years.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So mid-teens is pretty stable now?
componenttext: Okay. So mid-teens is pretty stable now?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2016
