headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jason Kupferberg of Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jason Kupferberg of Jefferies.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Cary for Jason. I know you called out weakness in the petrol-linked economies, and I think you said that Saudi Arabia, which had managed to avoid much of the slowdown has also been starting to slow. Any update you can provide on your expectat
componenttext: This is Ryan Cary for Jason. I know you called out weakness in the petrol-linked economies, and I think you said that Saudi Arabia, which had managed to avoid much of the slowdown has also been starting to slow. Any update you can provide on your expectations for these regions would be appreciated. And then maybe remind us what percent of C2C revs comes from the primary quarters impacted by lower oil prices?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So good question. Generally, the main impact on our business may be on the weakness of the oil-related countries, Libya and Nigeria. Saudi Arabia had a little bit slower, but it was not the major impact. The major impact was Libya and Nigeria and that's b
componenttext: So good question. Generally, the main impact on our business may be on the weakness of the oil-related countries, Libya and Nigeria. Saudi Arabia had a little bit slower, but it was not the major impact. The major impact was Libya and Nigeria and that's because of -- they're oil-producing and oil-related economies. In general, OPEC countries, if you take the OPEC countries, is about 10% to 15% of our revenues. So that puts us in perspective. And some of the -- we still see good growth in UAE. We still see good growth in some parts of the businesses, but some parts of the business, I have to be cautious also, because like Saudi Arabia where some investments have been slowed down, some construction, some hotels, some big airports, have been slowed down and that impacted definitely the workforce there respective to the remittance market. And that slowed down. We could see it. And once the oil prices are getting more stable, I'm sure that that's going to go back again. But currently, we do see a little bit impact from that area.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And how should we be thinking about compliance trends going forward? It seems like this has remained relatively consistent kind of at the lower end of the 3.5% to 4% range. Is that the right way to be thinking about it? And then anything you
componenttext: Okay, great. And how should we be thinking about compliance trends going forward? It seems like this has remained relatively consistent kind of at the lower end of the 3.5% to 4% range. Is that the right way to be thinking about it? And then anything you see on the horizon that could cause results to trend either above or below that range?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, generally, we say that we see compliance as a part of our business, right, business as usual and we see it also long-term competitive advantage. One example is the Southwest Border primary agreement that we completed, and we've definitely upgraded o
componenttext: Well, generally, we say that we see compliance as a part of our business, right, business as usual and we see it also long-term competitive advantage. One example is the Southwest Border primary agreement that we completed, and we've definitely upgraded our compliance programs and in many countries, we also see that Western Union is a preferred partner because of the compliance programs we put in place. I think the investment will continue. I don't see bigger changes. We operate in 200 countries, and the regulatory environment constantly is changing and the team is doing a great job investing in the technology, but also in the people to extend our licenses, also. But also, remainder in the country being active and being a competitive advantage. And I think -- and protect our consumers, that's our main goal. And since the last few years, we increasingly invested in the compliance environment, $200-plus million every year, and that's probably is really also protecting our consumers.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from Ashwin Shirvaikar of Citi.
componenttext: And the next question will come from Ashwin Shirvaikar of Citi.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, Raj, you've given some of this information in the course of the call, but I just want to clarify. As I look at the next 12 months, right, we should continue from a cost perspective see the impact of hedge roll-offs with minor uptick in the sec
componenttext: So I guess, Raj, you've given some of this information in the course of the call, but I just want to clarify. As I look at the next 12 months, right, we should continue from a cost perspective see the impact of hedge roll-offs with minor uptick in the second half. Tech cost continue to go up. I'm looking at can compensation restructuring continue to be the offset so that you can guide up on margins?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, our outlook for margins this year, Ashwin, is 20%, and that's really based on everything that we know at this stage. Clearly, we'll have some more hedge gains in the second part of this year and some of the hedge gains will continue into next year
componenttext: I mean, our outlook for margins this year, Ashwin, is 20%, and that's really based on everything that we know at this stage. Clearly, we'll have some more hedge gains in the second part of this year and some of the hedge gains will continue into next year as well. But there are a number of other factors that are going to drive margins and profitability. Hedges are just one component. You have cost savings as well, but commissions and compliance costs have been relatively stable. That should be -- that's stable for this year, and we've been able to stabilize those the last couple of years, so that's positive. But we don't really have an outlook for next year, if that's what you're getting at, Ashwin, but we feel good about the outlook for this year.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: However, we are very much focused, Ashwin, on revenue growth and profit growth, and profitable growth and revenue growth, that's our focus.
componenttext: However, we are very much focused, Ashwin, on revenue growth and profit growth, and profitable growth and revenue growth, that's our focus.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, obviously, revenue growth also helps the cause. I guess, Hikmet, a question for you with regards to digital mobile becoming such a big part of how people access the network and the system. Is there any change in how you think of your agent networ
componenttext: Yes. No, obviously, revenue growth also helps the cause. I guess, Hikmet, a question for you with regards to digital mobile becoming such a big part of how people access the network and the system. Is there any change in how you think of your agent network with regards to the kind of deals you can structure with them with regards to their compensation and so on, so forth? Any update there would help.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ashwin, currently not. So I think that our agent commissions has been favorable for Western Union over the years, as you know. And definitely, the new agreements we signed has not been signing at the rates we signed years ago. Obviously, that helped
componenttext: Yes, Ashwin, currently not. So I think that our agent commissions has been favorable for Western Union over the years, as you know. And definitely, the new agreements we signed has not been signing at the rates we signed years ago. Obviously, that helped also. However, I would like to keep and grow my agent network because one of the biggest things we see is that the new customers, which we sign with mobile want to drop money on our retail money transfer, retail locations worldwide, right? We do have, for instance, in India, more than 100,000 locations and you can send money immediately from Denver, from your mobile phone immediately to 100,000 locations in India, plus the thousands of millions of millions of accounts in India in a moment. And nobody else can do that, that big, as we can do it, That's a big competitive advantage. Seeing that also, we're always looking for optimization for our sales cost, for our retail costs, and I think that team is working very hard on that. And I think long term, there's definitely some room there to be more efficient.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Danyal Hussain of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question comes from Danyal Hussain of Morgan Stanley.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to clarify the $0.01 guidance change. Seems like before we were assuming tax to be 15% and we lowered that to 12% for the year, that's $0.06 when you factor in the $0.02 from the accrual. So I guess I am looking for the other $0.03, so some of that
componenttext: I want to clarify the $0.01 guidance change. Seems like before we were assuming tax to be 15% and we lowered that to 12% for the year, that's $0.06 when you factor in the $0.02 from the accrual. So I guess I am looking for the other $0.03, so some of that looks like they have been FX headwinds. I'm wondering what else is in there?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Danyal, this is Raj. Our outlook for the full year, it does take into account the tax benefits. I would say, the $0.06 that you're calculating is a little bit high. If you -- our new outlook for the tax rate is around 12%, and we had given a mid-teen
componenttext: Yes, Danyal, this is Raj. Our outlook for the full year, it does take into account the tax benefits. I would say, the $0.06 that you're calculating is a little bit high. If you -- our new outlook for the tax rate is around 12%, and we had given a mid-teens level. So depending on where -- what you assume for the actual tax rate, you'll have to walk down from that, but I would say, your estimate is a little bit high. And then we have a $0.02 offset to that from the legal accruals, so that's why we've moved up the low end of the range by the net $0.02 effectively, and so that's how we look at it. Nothing really has changed from our operating outlook. We still have the same revenue growth outlook, low- to mid-single digits constant currency, profit margins at around 20%. And then, our reported revenue is going to be a little bit lower than we thought in the last quarter, but most of that revenue change is going to be -- the profit impact of that is going to be offset with the increased hedge gains. So we now expect about $45 million in hedge gains this year versus $40 million that we said in the last quarter. So all that is netting out to have no real operating impact, and so we've reflected the 2 key items, the taxes and the legal accrual.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That makes sense. And I just wanted to clarify the -- so this quarter you were able to offset the Argentina pricing impact with FX spreads. I guess I just wanted to understand better how sustainable that is? And how those spreads -- like, do they
componenttext: Got it. That makes sense. And I just wanted to clarify the -- so this quarter you were able to offset the Argentina pricing impact with FX spreads. I guess I just wanted to understand better how sustainable that is? And how those spreads -- like, do they benefit, for example, when you have higher FX volatility? Would we expect those to normalize? Or is this, I guess, a more sustainable spread?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there are 3 things that are in the second quarter from a pricing investment standpoint. We are still seeing the Argentina impact as I mentioned. Secondly, we did grow over the domestic money transfer pricings that we did last year in April, so we're
componenttext: Yes, there are 3 things that are in the second quarter from a pricing investment standpoint. We are still seeing the Argentina impact as I mentioned. Secondly, we did grow over the domestic money transfer pricings that we did last year in April, so we're getting a benefit from that. And then third, we did raise some spreads in certain parts of the world. I would say on the spread changes, we have 16,000 quarters that we're monitoring pricing activity and pricing levels and we try to optimize those on an ongoing basis. So I wouldn't characterize these as things that stay forever. We may increase spreads, we may reduce spreads. It really depends on what those particular markets require. So that's really the way I would look at the spread changes.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Oscar Turner of SunTrust.
componenttext: The next question comes from Oscar Turner of SunTrust.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you talked a bit about your competitive advantage in mobile coming from allowing send to either retail locations or accounts. Can you provide any color into transaction or volume growth by payout method? So looking at either transfers to retail account
componenttext: So you talked a bit about your competitive advantage in mobile coming from allowing send to either retail locations or accounts. Can you provide any color into transaction or volume growth by payout method? So looking at either transfers to retail accounts versus just to accounts and how that has trended?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think one of the biggest competitive advantage is the retail and stays retail. Most of the transactions are paid out in money in minutes in retail in cash. And that continues, especially international fund -- outbound ones are happening. But we do
componenttext: Yes. I think one of the biggest competitive advantage is the retail and stays retail. Most of the transactions are paid out in money in minutes in retail in cash. And that continues, especially international fund -- outbound ones are happening. But we do see very, very strong part -- certain countries like in South Asian countries that the people do prefer also accounts and our promotions on the westernunion.com has been very successful there, that we can grow -- we grew our account payout also in some countries. In some countries, we're just building it. We have now billions of accounts worldwide in 50 countries, and reminds me a little bit, right, of how we build the retail money transfer business. Build it, they will come, and we are really building now the account network worldwide, now billions of accounts, and now it's all about communicating and building the corridor building, making marketing and promotions. But still, most of the payouts are on the retail payouts, but very strong growth in certain countries, certain corridors also on the account payout.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just looking at your account-to-account, I guess, initiative, could you provide any color on account-to-account volume growth in the quarter? And also at what point will this start influencing your revenue growth?
componenttext: Okay. And then just looking at your account-to-account, I guess, initiative, could you provide any color on account-to-account volume growth in the quarter? And also at what point will this start influencing your revenue growth?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when it comes material, definitely we will give you more color on that. It's in the beginning, but it's very strong growth. The big advantage here is that funding method is done by accounts. You have immediately, the funds in mobile, you collect the
componenttext: Yes, when it comes material, definitely we will give you more color on that. It's in the beginning, but it's very strong growth. The big advantage here is that funding method is done by accounts. You have immediately, the funds in mobile, you collect the money immediately from funds. You have -- we do have it in the U.S., but also very strong in Europe where we have a direct ACH transit, Direct Debit, they call it in Europe, and we collect the money immediately from an account and drop in an account worldwide on billions of which country, more than 50 countries. And the other thing is that we see more banks calling us actually on that, could you do this transaction for us because you have the technology, they tell us; you have the compliance programs, which they have to build it globally, we do have it in 200 countries. So it started to be getting a kind of advantage kind of a focus. But again, we just build billions of accounts and now we are really designing a product against this account-to-account transactions.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question will come from Rayna Kumar of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question will come from Rayna Kumar of Evercore ISI.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now that PayPal has owned Xoom for roughly a year, have you experienced any impact to your online business?
componenttext: Now that PayPal has owned Xoom for roughly a year, have you experienced any impact to your online business?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the results really speak for themselves. You can see the great growth that we're getting in our wu.com business 25% transaction growth and 20% revenue growth in constant currency, and we have a business that's much broader than just the U.S.
componenttext: Well, I think the results really speak for themselves. You can see the great growth that we're getting in our wu.com business 25% transaction growth and 20% revenue growth in constant currency, and we have a business that's much broader than just the U.S., right? We have a business that's in 37 countries, and we continue to expand those capabilities on an ongoing basis. We already deliver around the world in 200 countries and territories around the world. And then our account payout capabilities are getting even stronger. And the unique thing about the account payout is that it's direct delivery into these accounts. It's not going through the corresponding banking system. And so even the newer players, they're playing only in the online space, online to account or account to account, they're not playing in the retail space, which is where we have our brand, so that's not the place they're coming after. And as you know, our digital business plays out mostly in the retail locations today, right, but the growth opportunity for us is also paying -- doing account-to-account or online to account. And we think we're going to create a better and stronger business there than anybody else will be able to create.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: What progress have you made in offering instant ACH?
componenttext: What progress have you made in offering instant ACH?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, most of the transaction in the U.S., instant ACH is a very U.S.-focused question, I guess, and most of the transactions in the U.S. are still done by credit cards and the people prefer credit cards. We have it, but we see that most of the people wan
componenttext: Well, most of the transaction in the U.S., instant ACH is a very U.S.-focused question, I guess, and most of the transactions in the U.S. are still done by credit cards and the people prefer credit cards. We have it, but we see that most of the people want to use their credit cards to fund the transaction. We do see also strong growth on the ACH on -- in Europe. They don't call it ACH there. There's direct debit. There are companies like SOFORT. They help us to do that, pull out money from the banks, from consumer accounts and that's growing also very well, but most of the transactions on the send side is still done by credit cards.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next we have a question from John Davis of Stifel.
componenttext: And next we have a question from John Davis of Stifel.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wondering if you could maybe comment on any potential impact of the EU's new AML directive that just came out recently? Any impact there or thoughts would be helpful.
componenttext: Wondering if you could maybe comment on any potential impact of the EU's new AML directive that just came out recently? Any impact there or thoughts would be helpful.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think that has had any impact on our business, currently. We do -- we probably follow the European Union rules, obviously, and we don't see any big impact to our business because we've been doing this already, the regulations and we adopted them a
componenttext: I don't think that has had any impact on our business, currently. We do -- we probably follow the European Union rules, obviously, and we don't see any big impact to our business because we've been doing this already, the regulations and we adopted them already. And one of the biggest things also is that don't forget that we forget sometimes to mention it, we do have a bank license in the European Union, which is licensed in 27 European Union countries and that helps us also. That also is a competitive advantage here. And then we did invest a lot on our anti-money laundering activities in the European Union and we worked closely with regulators there. I don't see big impact here.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then Raj, maybe a housekeeping item. I think assuming that the tax rate is going to benefit from onetime items this year, is it safe to assume that it will likely trend back to the mid-teens next year?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then Raj, maybe a housekeeping item. I think assuming that the tax rate is going to benefit from onetime items this year, is it safe to assume that it will likely trend back to the mid-teens next year?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. I would even say for this year, if we didn't have the various discrete items that we talked about, we would be in the mid-teens range as we had originally thought, and we're not giving specific guidance for next year. But given what we know toda
componenttext: Yes, yes. I would even say for this year, if we didn't have the various discrete items that we talked about, we would be in the mid-teens range as we had originally thought, and we're not giving specific guidance for next year. But given what we know today and tax legislations evolving all around the world, we would be probably in the mid-teens range for the next couple of years. But we need to see how things play out around the world as you know, those things are evolving all the time.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And finally, I think Raj you mentioned on the call that 30% of the cash is in the U.S., so I think that's puts at around $360 million. Then assume you're going to generate another $100-plus million in free cash flow in the back half of this year, th
componenttext: Okay. And finally, I think Raj you mentioned on the call that 30% of the cash is in the U.S., so I think that's puts at around $360 million. Then assume you're going to generate another $100-plus million in free cash flow in the back half of this year, that kind of gets you to a $475 million-ish cash number in the U.S, and that's roughly what you paid out in the first half of the year. So maybe just talk a little bit about the internal cash management policies and procedures you guys use kind of help give us comfort that there's plenty of cash in the U.S. to pay dividends and repurchases as we go into '17?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, absolutely. Our dividends are easily payable and that's something that we have a heavy focus on, obviously. We do have intercompany working capital programs that allow us to free up more cash here in the U.S. And I would also say that over time
componenttext: Yes, well, absolutely. Our dividends are easily payable and that's something that we have a heavy focus on, obviously. We do have intercompany working capital programs that allow us to free up more cash here in the U.S. And I would also say that over time, we also will have more capacity from a debt standpoint. So there's plenty of availability of capital and the way we manage our cash overall. So I have no concerns there.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Western Union Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mike Salop, Senior Vice President of Investor
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Western Union Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mike Salop, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laura. On today's call, Hikmet Ersek, Western Union's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Raj Agrawal, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer will discuss the company's 2015 third quarter results, and then we'll take your q
componenttext: Thank you, Laura. On today's call, Hikmet Ersek, Western Union's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Raj Agrawal, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer will discuss the company's 2015 third quarter results, and then we'll take your questions. The slides that accompany this call and webcast can be found at westernunion.com under the Investor Relations tab and will remain available after the call. Additional operational statistics have been provided in supplemental tables with our press release. Today's call is being recorded, and our comments include forward-looking statements. Please refer to the cautionary language in the earnings release and in Western Union's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the 2015 Form 10-K, for additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements. During the call, we will discuss some items that do not conform to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. We've reconciled those items to the most comparable GAAP measures on our website, westernunion.com, under the Investor Relations section. All statements made by Western Union officers on this call are the property of the Western Union Company and subject to copyright protection. Other than the replay noted in our press release, Western Union has not authorized and disclaims responsibility for any recording, replay or distribution of any transcription of this call. I would now like turn the call over to Hikmet Ersek.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good afternoon, everyone. Overall, we're pleased that our diversified global business and strategic initiatives enables us to deliver another solid earnings performance in the third quarter. And we accomplished this, while mitigating
componenttext: Thank you, Mike, and good afternoon, everyone. Overall, we're pleased that our diversified global business and strategic initiatives enables us to deliver another solid earnings performance in the third quarter. And we accomplished this, while mitigating currency headwinds and challenges in some international markets. Our U.S. business remains strong. And westernunion.com money transfer accelerated nicely, increasing 28% in constant currency. This growth help us balance all related softness in many of the Middle East and African countries. We delivered good margins coming in at over 20% despite negative impact from currency and the legal matter accrual and we continue to generate strong cash flow and return significant funds to our shareholders. We are on track to deliver on our full year earnings outlook and are affirming our earnings per share range of $1.60 to $1.70. Total revenue in the quarter increased 2% on a constant-currency basis with the consumer money transfer business increasing 1%. Within money transfer, the U.S. business was strong across the Board with good growth from both and domestic money transfer. Our U.S. to Mexico business continues to shine and has now outpaced market growth for principal and transactions in each quarter for the past 3 years. In addition, we recently greatly expanded distribution in Mexico, nearly doubling our network. This was driven by the activation of our transfers, services at OXO, which is Mexico's largest convenience store geographically with 14,000 locations. With this new service, customers can make transactions on the form in advance or through dedicated Forms and digital kiosk in the stores, and then receive their funds at the counter. Turning to westernunion.com, this quarter's revenue increase is impressive, given the larger size of our digital business relative to competitors. We continue to see tremendous growth from the up and the westernunion.com business was particularly strong in the U.S. market. We also continued to expand our digital assets, rolling out mobile apps in Canada and additional countries in Europe, giving a 16 transactional mobile apps in the market among our 37 westernunion.com countries. In addition, in the U.S. and U.K., we have added new omni channel feature to our mobile apps. The customers can now fund same transactions from mobile apps via cards, accounts and also cash. This new feature allows consumers to start transactions on their smartphones and then pay with cash at agent locations, adding convenient and reduce time for in-store transactions. As I mentioned earlier, from all the in countries had been affected by the low oil price environment. While this is not a new factor, we did see a softening in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, key markets in the Gulf that had largely maintain growth trends until the middle of the year. Overall, the C2C pricing and competitive environment remains quite stable, as we had not seen significant changes in the marketplace. While there were some announcement recently concerning price changes for competitive services in limited areas, we don't anticipate this having significant impact on our business. We are very well positioned in the U.S. to Mexico with our 50,000 agent locations in the U.S. and 26,000 in Mexico and a very competitive fee of $8 on cents up to $1,000. In the U.S. domestic money transfer market, all the certain competitors are lowering fees on very high principal transfers, this is a small piece of our business to date. To put this in perspective, U.S. domestic money transfers over $1,000 represent less than 1% of company revenue. So overall, we are competitive with our current C2C product and pricing strategy, and for the new feature, we do not anticipate major companywide pricing adjustments. Turning to our -- to the other segments. The consumer bill payment business again delivered double-digit constant currency growth in the quarter, while Business Solutions was flat. All the business solutions had good growth from its payment products, especially verticals, such as serving clients in the education sector, reductions in customers hedging activities, negatively impacted results. Strategically, we continue to advance our edge digital platform for importers and exporters. We have enabled thousands of business clients for use of the platform, which recently won payments innovation award in London. Overall, we remain on track to deliver our earnings outlook even with the many challenges we had faced this year. Our strong financial position has allowed us to continue investing in our platforms including advancements in our digital, technology and compliance assets and programs. And we are intent on further expanding our capabilities and network of digital and physical touch points. These includes agent locations, mobile, online, account and kiosk, both direct and through our agent partners, as we leverage our platforms to offer consumers and businesses freedom of choice in how and when they want to move money across We will talk more about our long-term strategies in the coming months. But right now I want to turn the call over to Raj to discuss the third quarter results in more detail.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Hikmet. Third quarter reported revenues of $1.4 million declined 2% or increased 2% on a constant-currency basis compared to the prior-year period. The impact of currency translation net of hedge benefits reduced third quarter revenue by approx
componenttext: Thank you, Hikmet. Third quarter reported revenues of $1.4 million declined 2% or increased 2% on a constant-currency basis compared to the prior-year period. The impact of currency translation net of hedge benefits reduced third quarter revenue by approximately $52 million compared to the prior year. In the Consumer-to-Consumer segment, revenues declined 1% in the quarter or increased 1% constant currency, while transactions grew 2%. C2C constant currency revenue benefited from strong growth in westernunion.com, while regional growth was led by North America and Latin America. However, softness from the oil-producing countries continue to negatively impact the Middle East and Africa and part of the Asia-Pacific region. Total C2C cross-border principal declined 3% or 2% on a constant-currency basis, while principal per transaction declined 5% or 4% in constant currency terms. The spread between the C2C transaction growth and the revenue decline in the quarter was approximately 3 percentage points, including a negative 2% impact in currency. Mix had a negative impact of approximately 2% in the quarter and was affected by the principal per transaction decline, while pricing had a positive impact of 1%. Turning to the regions. Consistent with prior quarters, I will be referring to constant currency movements as I discuss individual country contributions to the regional results. North America continue to deliver strong results in the quarter -- in the third quarter. Revenue grew 6% or 7% on a constant-currency basis, while transactions increased 7%. U.S. outbound sends to Mexico and Latin America drove the region's revenue growth. In Mexico, our business continued to grow faster than the market based on the latest Banco de Mexico principal and transaction data for the third quarter. Our U.S. domestic money transfer business also posted good results as revenue increased 4% and transaction growth improved to 5%. In the Europe and CIS region, revenue declined 2% or increased 1% on a constant-currency basis, while transactions increased 2%. Revenue growth was driven by Greece and the U.K., partially offset by declines in Turkey. As a reminder, Greece was impacted in the third quarter of last year by government market restrictions on money transfers during the country's financial crisis. In the Middle East and Africa region, revenue declined 10% or 8% in constant currency and transactions were down 9%. Low oil prices continue to affect the region's results in the quarter, which tends weakening since last quarter in Saudi Arabia, Angola and the UAE. In the Asia Pacific region, revenue was down 4% or 3% constant currency, while transactions decreased 5%. Receive markets in the region, including India, continue to be negatively impacted by lower inventories from the oil-producing countries. Revenue in the Latin America and Caribbean region grew 3% and increased 8% constant currency, while transactions grew 12%. Revenue growth in the region was largely driven by strong inbound business from the U.S. Included in the regional numbers discussed, westernunion.com C2C revenue growth accelerated to 26% in the quarter or 28% constant currency and represented 8% of total C2C revenue. Westernunion.com transactions increased 29%, while U.S. originated online transactions grew 33%. In the Consumer-to-Business segment, revenue declined 3% or increased to 11% on a constant-currency basis. Consequence, revenue was driven by the Argentina walk-in and U.S. electronic businesses, which is partially offset by the declines in U.S. cash walk-ins. The depreciation of the Argentine peso continue to declined in the reported revenues. Business Solutions revenue declined 4%; on a constant-currency basis revenues, were flat. As good growth in Europe was offset by reduced customer hedging activities, particularly in Australia and an Canada. Turning to margins and profitability. The consolidated operating margin was 20.2% in the quarter compared to 21.8% in the prior-year period. This quarter's operating margin was negatively impacted by 110 basis points from a $15 million accrual related to the previously disclosed SEC legal matter. This is an addition to the $15 million for this in the second quarter as we have not reached resolution with the SEC at this time. Other negative impacts from the margin included foreign exchange, customer and funding mix in the electronic bill payments business and incremental technology expense, which were partially offset by lower compensation and depreciation and amortization expenses. Foreign exchange gains in the quarter were $12 million compared to $21 million of gains in the third quarter of last year. We continue to expect approximately $45 million in hedge gains for the year. Based on recent rates in our current hedge position, we currently project about $15 million of gains for 2017. In total, currency negatively impacted operating profit by approximately $22 million in the quarter compared to the same period last year. Compliance expense has been steady and came in at 3.5% of revenue in the quarter. EBITDA margin was 25.0%, down from 27.1% in the prior year period as a result of the same negative factors that affected operating margin. The tax rate of 9.6% benefited from a 160 basis points impact from the FTC accrual in compared to 12.5% in the third quarter of last year. We still expect the full year rate of approximately 12%. Earnings per share was $0.44 in the quarter, including a negative $0.02 impact for the additional FTC accrual and compared to $0.45 in the third quarter of last year. The C2C segment operating margin of 23.4% was down from 25.5% in the prior year, and was negatively affected by 140 basis points from the accrual. The C2C margin was also negatively impacted by foreign exchange and higher technology expense, which were partially offset by lower compensation-related costs. The Consumer-to-Business operating margin was 9.1% in the quarter compared to 16.4% in the prior year. The margin decline was primarily due to customer and funding mix in the U.S. electronic business. The mix impacts relate to the addition of a large new of lower margins and general increase credit card usage of the funding option by consumers. Business Solutions operating profit was $3 million or a 3.5% margin compared to a loss of $3 million in the prior year period. The operating profit improvement was driven by lower depreciation and amortization expense, which relates to the write-down for a contract termination in the third quarter of last year. Depreciation and amortization for Business Solutions was approximately $30 million in the quarter compared to a $20 million in the prior year. The Business Solutions EBITDA margin was 17.1%, which compared to 17.4% in the third quarter of last year. Turning to our cash flow and balance sheet. Cash flow from operating activities were $822 million year-to-date through September. Capital expenditures were $68 million in the quarter. At the end of the quarter, we have $3.2 billion in cash of $1.3 billion with approximately 50% of the cash held by The United States entities. After the quarter, in October, we retired $1 billion in maturing notes, which had a coupon of 5.93%. We're funded this maturity by drawing down on a $575 million term loan facility, which carries interest rate of LIBOR plus 150. And through a combination of cash usage and commercial issuance. During the third quarter, we repaid $78 million in dividends and repurchased approximately 4 million shares for a total of $84 million. Our remaining authorization, which expires in December 2017 was $310 million at quarter end and the outstanding share count at the end of September was 485 million shares. Turning to our outlook for the full year. We are narrowing the revenue growth outlook, while affirming operating profit margin, the EPS range and operating cash flow. The updated revenue outlook for the year is an increase of approximately 3% constant currency, which should translate to a decrease of approximately 1% on a GAAP basis. Operating profit margin for the full year, remained approximately 20%, while EPS remains in the range of $1.60 to $1.70. We have been able to maintain the margin outlook despite the unanticipated $30 million of legal matter accruals during the year due to favorability in other expenses. We continue to expect to generate $1 billion in cash flow from operating activities and we now expect the $100 million of anticipated final tax payment related to the previously announced IRS agreement we paid in 2017. So to summarize, we delivered solid results for the quarter and remain on track with our full year earnings outlook. Our cash flow and balance sheet are strong and we continue to return significant funds to shareholders. Operator, we are now ready to take questions.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

Clearly low, oil prices continue to be a headwind to results, can we expect negative growth as kind of the new normal for the time being in the petro producing regions or is the impact less structural in these regions could occur relatively quickly with the rebounded in energy prices?

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we did see some impact, which especially from the Middle East and Middle East related oil producing countries, that's the fact. But I will say overall being in 200 countries having that portfolio, that balances the strong U.S. growth, the str
componenttext: Yes, I think we did see some impact, which especially from the Middle East and Middle East related oil producing countries, that's the fact. But I will say overall being in 200 countries having that portfolio, that balances the strong U.S. growth, the strong westernunion.com digital growth, accelerating the transactions and revenue is a really great results. It has, I would say, it takes time, right? If all these prices are higher, the jobs have to be created, the investments have to be done in Saudi Arabia or UAE and Middle East countries. That creates jobs. And if the people have jobs, they send money. But as you know, putting things in perspective, it's a good part of business, but not that big part of business and being 200 countries helps us to have good results.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just follow up. How should we be thinking about the tax rate going forward? I believe, you call expectations for kind of mid-teen over the next couple of years. It seems like over the last 3 to 4, often been initial assumption before coming cou
componenttext: Great. And just follow up. How should we be thinking about the tax rate going forward? I believe, you call expectations for kind of mid-teen over the next couple of years. It seems like over the last 3 to 4, often been initial assumption before coming couple of hundred basis points later. Is it the trend that we should expect to continue going forward or -- I mean, I'm trying to get a sense of how we should think about the tax rate, particularly, kind of lighter than expected this quarter?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, this is Raj. We still targeted mid-teens tax rate and that's still what we expect for the next couple of years based on what we know today about tax loss and the current environment with our business. We continue to benefit from some discreet items
componenttext: Ryan, this is Raj. We still targeted mid-teens tax rate and that's still what we expect for the next couple of years based on what we know today about tax loss and the current environment with our business. We continue to benefit from some discreet items that have helped us during the course of the year. In this quarter, for example, we honestly, we got a benefit from the larger accrual in the U.S., which helps the mix on the overall tax rate. We also have some favorable resolutions to sustaining tax matters with various governments around the world. And so that continues to help us and we're going to continue to try to do that as much as we can. Putting aside the discreet items, we are probably in that mid-teens rate, which is what we fully expect when we came into this year. But we're doing a good job in trying to manage things as best as we can on the tax side and that continues to be our goal.

So customers are returning using us, they love the app, the westernunion.com app. Our transactions in the U.S. are growing by 33%. And that's amazing and we're really gaining their market share and getting new customers. Still the customers are new. 80% of the customers are using westernunion.com digital environment, are new to Western Union. They didn't use last 12 months they didn't use 12 months.

componenttext: In the Westernunion.com,  16 countries on mobile app. And we recently also launched new features in Canada and U.K. where you can transaction if somebody doesn't want to use bank account or credit card, they can go to a location and transaction, pay at the location. So these things are definitely in multi-product and multi-channel environments helping. The other thing is also, what the competitors don't have and that's why they're not growing that fast is that we're in 200 countries. We can drop money in 16,000 corridors with 1 app. From Canada, you can send money to 200 countries. From U.K., can send money to 200 countries. From 37 countries, electronic to digital, you can send money. That's the growth part. We're very pleased with our digital growth and that's going to continue, our investment is going to continue. And my expectations will be -- I'm very motivated with that.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good to hear. And then maybe just as a quick follow-up. There's been a lot of headlines around the Wal-Mart U.S. to Mexico kind of pricing structures that they recently published, can maybe talk about whether you expect any potential knock on affec
componenttext: That's good to hear. And then maybe just as a quick follow-up. There's been a lot of headlines around the Wal-Mart U.S. to Mexico kind of pricing structures that they recently published, can maybe talk about whether you expect any potential knock on affect relative to the rest of the market, and I know Wal-Mart is pretty small, but still, I guess, there is a speculation about whether that could have a broader market or where you think it's just going to be confined to simply Wal-Mart?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't say Wal-Mart in small, in particularly, but In this business, it is small. We've 50,000 locations in the U.S. and 26,000 locations in Mexico. And our pricing has been very compatible $8 for up to $1,000. And the fact speaks its language. We're
componenttext: I wouldn't say Wal-Mart in small, in particularly, but In this business, it is small. We've 50,000 locations in the U.S. and 26,000 locations in Mexico. And our pricing has been very compatible $8 for up to $1,000. And the fact speaks its language. We're been gaining market share for 3 years every quarter and these facts are from Banco de Mexico facts. So the distribution, the product positioning, the pricing, the brand, the compliance programs, all these platforms help us to be gaining market share. So we will always do pricing actions quarter by quarter. We will look at that. But I feel quite competitive with our pricing and I see the pricing is very stable and we're going to continue hopefully gaining market share in this very important corridor for us.

componenttext: Well, Tien-tsin, you know, our business very well. As you know, we are in so many countries, so many bands, so many different things. We feel comfortable by gaining market share also in some corridors increasing the FX rates that helped also and its mix. Basically, the mix is not the big increase. componenttext: Sure. On Business Solutions, if you look at the Business Solutions, we're very pleased with our payment sector. The verticals, where the students pay as a payment. Saying that, we're still very important for us, that's why invest in digital platform. We have thousands of exporters, importers registered there. They're trading in this platform. And that will be definitely helping on long-term on our numbers. But short-term volatility will help us and global will help us.

But you can see that through the first 3 quarters and even the third quarter, we got an EPS of $0.44, which is very much in line with our expectations and we feel good about the full year outlook.

componenttext: Just on the quick follow-up around the margin. It does seem like items there, and obviously you've been able to maintain it relatively stable despite that. In other words, if you were to show 3% growth once again in 2017, I mean, is there any reason to see -- to expect to not being able to expect some margin expansion on that?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Darrin, I can't talk about 2017 margins. But the reason we're been able to maintain the margin this year at around 20% is we have managed our expenses quite well, even though we've taken into account an additional $30 million of legal cost, we're bee
componenttext: Yes. Darrin, I can't talk about 2017 margins. But the reason we're been able to maintain the margin this year at around 20% is we have managed our expenses quite well, even though we've taken into account an additional $30 million of legal cost, we're been able to do that. For us, obviously, we need to get good revenue growth to drive better profitability. But then you have to look at other cost items that will have an impact, obviously, like which have been flat the last couple of years. Our compliance costs have also been relatively stable at that 3.5% to 4% range. And as I just mentioned earlier, we'll continue to look for cost optimization opportunities. So all of those things will have an impact and we'll more color for you on those things we finish of the year. But the margin this year, we're pleased with the 20% operating margin outlook even in the face of some other things that we had to deal with.

componenttext: Okay. And just a quick follow up on the guidance question. I mean, understand you seeing 3% and a lot outcomes that get there. But I guess, I'm just trying to figure out what may have been in your expectations beforehand could be low to mid-single digit top line versus now 3%, what changed I guess, and again, we understand it's not a massive move from one to the other, but anything would be helpful?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been running at 3% from the first half of the year on a constant-currency basis. And we still had 6 months left in the year when we maintained our outlook last quarter, low to mid digits. But as we've seen a tick down in the business given the
componenttext: Well, we've been running at 3% from the first half of the year on a constant-currency basis. And we still had 6 months left in the year when we maintained our outlook last quarter, low to mid digits. But as we've seen a tick down in the business given the oil-related markets, we're more comfortable with the 3% revenue growth outlook because of the performance that we had in the third quarter. And it's really the Middle East and the oil-related markets that have shown a tick down because we're continuing to get very strong growth in the other markets like the U.S., Mexico to Latin America, the domestic business, the digital business obviously. And so those trends haven't really changed. We've seen just to tick down in the Middle East and Africa, which has impacted APAC as well.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Just last quick one, on the mobile side. Last quarter, I know you guys had a bit of spread between the revenue growth and transaction growth. It actually looked like mentioned earlier, by someone, it definitely improved any I you know comm
componenttext: That's helpful. Just last quick one, on the mobile side. Last quarter, I know you guys had a bit of spread between the revenue growth and transaction growth. It actually looked like mentioned earlier, by someone, it definitely improved any I you know commented on mobile being driver of the acceleration on wu.com, but can help us understand why the revenue per transaction would have improved so much given how much is mobile?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're continuing to see very strong growth in the mobile channel for wu.com and we're pleased with that, so that haven't changed from before. As we mentioned before, we do pricing optimization throughout our business including our various channels an
componenttext: Yes. We're continuing to see very strong growth in the mobile channel for wu.com and we're pleased with that, so that haven't changed from before. As we mentioned before, we do pricing optimization throughout our business including our various channels and we did increase some spreads in the  .com business. But our overall pricing in the .com business is very market competitive when you look at the rest of the competitions. So we're just very aligning and maximizing the opportunity there. And we're getting very consistent growth with transaction growth, 29% transaction growth and 28% constant revenue growth. It's a pretty consistent picture and it's very consistent with what we had expected coming into the second half of this year.

componenttext: So I have a question about that legal accrual, I think presentation did mention that there was an offset compensation in DNA, if you could size that, that would be helpful? componenttext: Yes. I'm not trying to answer your questions. In the SG&A line, as you mentioned, we had the FTC legal accrual for $50 million, that's the size of it. There were some offsets with lower compensation and lower DNA. And SG&A, as a percentage of revenues, was up just a little bit from the last year. So I'd just like you do the math, but there was a slight...

componenttext: And the rest of it is just the comp. As you look at next year, I can't really go into specifics, but there are a number of different factors to consider all the things that I mentioned in previous question around revenue growth as well as the various cost items, but tax will certainly be a consideration. Putting aside any discrete items as I mentioned, earlier for the next couple of years will be probably the mid-teens area for tax rate. But as I also mentioned, we're always trying to look for opportunities to optimize our tax rate. We will have some interest savings as we go into next year because of the refinancing that we just did. amount of interest saving will depend on our debt level and then we also have a refinancing to make sure that we have to do some maybe some negative carry related to that. And then we also have the hedge gains that will exactly where they're today, then we'll have less in hedge gain. So all of those things will have to come together and how we ultimately look from a profit standpoint.

componenttextpreview: While I can't speak the competition what's their issues. Their issues, I guess, mostly the comp expense globally and they don't have the power to expand globally and they don't have -- they can't drop money to the billing accounts we have and they can't d
componenttext: While I can't speak the competition what's their issues. Their issues, I guess, mostly the comp expense globally and they don't have the power to expand globally and they don't have -- they can't drop money to the billing accounts we have and they can't drop money to 500,000 locations and everything, right? I think the strong growth is 2 things, Karthik. First one is the customers are coming back, who use once mobile, they love it, they stay there, they coming back. We see that very good. And that's the U.S. growth besides getting more customers, we are really having returning customers and the team is doing good job on that communicating with them online with via mobile, really motive -- having loyalty programs, which is getting back. The second thing is the geographical expansion. Expansion in Canada, expansion in U.K. with new devices, but also in Europe and now, we are starting to expand that also, you'll see recent announcement coming announcement in other countries in Asia in other parts of Europe and Middle East. We're going to expand our online and our activities and mobile activities. And it's a good business to expand. Raj?

componenttext: Well, if you look at the market, it's quite stable, right? I don't see any big noise up there. Part of the refinancing was was the term loan as I mentioned, in our comments, which is LIBOR plus 150 basis points, which is lower obviously than the note that we just at 5.93% and the recent We get interest savings there, but it might be offset with some other components here that I also mentioned. But should the oil economies not recover and the global economy remain suspect, do you've any other pricing leverage other than risk that you could use to reverse the decline in transaction growth?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at our business, I mean, there's a global challenge is for all, right. It's not a competitive challenge, it's for affects, everyone. I think that in the markets where we are, we feel very competitive with pricing. As I said earlier, we w
componenttext: Well, if you look at our business, I mean, there's a global challenge is for all, right. It's not a competitive challenge, it's for affects, everyone. I think that in the markets where we are, we feel very competitive with pricing. As I said earlier, we will always pricing. That's the beauty of having this portfolio. And we didn't do the 16,000 corridors, we've different customer we've different bands receiving FX and fees, so we can do that. We're going to continue to do that and I feel comfortable where it is. I think it does more noise up there with the announcements. And currently, near future, what I hear from my market leaders, they feel comfortable. What I hear from our digital leaders, they feel comfortable. That's -- and we are growing with our numbers, 28%, digital growth is impressive, a very stable, a very resilient retail business. And for the near future, I don't see, I can't predict the future -- long-term future, but I feel comfortable where the business is.

componenttext: Well, I can't predict the economy of the oil prices, right. I can't predict the global economy. And that's something I'm always cautious. And I said, beginning of the year, '16 is cautious and today still staying cautious, right. But the beauty of our business, if you look at our business, not only in the U.S., worldwide, we've been always ups and downs. And currently in the U.S., we are doing a good job, and business doing very well, digital doing very well. Parts of like U.K., although, there's Brexit and everything, U.K. business is doing very well. Our Australia business is doing very well. We do have impact in the Saudi Arabia and UAE, where they send money to mostly to South Asia. This corridor has been impacted. And that's why some parts of -- like India corridors has been a slower growth because Saudi Arabia send and UAE send has been slower.
