Good afternoon, and welcome to the Western Union Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Mike Salop, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Laura. On today's call, Hikmet Ersek, Western Union's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Raj Agrawal, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer will discuss the company's 2016 third quarter results, and then we'll take your q
componenttext:
Thank you, Laura. On today's call, Hikmet Ersek, Western Union's President and Chief Executive Officer; and Raj Agrawal, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer will discuss the company's 2016 third quarter results, and then we'll take your questions. The slides that accompany this call and webcast can be found at westernunion.com under the Investor Relations tab and will remain available after the call. Additional operational statistics have been provided in supplemental tables with our press release. 
Today's call is being recorded, and our comments include forward-looking statements. Please refer to the cautionary language in the earnings release and in Western Union's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including the 2015 Form 10-K, for additional information concerning factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from the forward-looking statements. 
During the call, we will discuss some items that do not conform to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. We've reconciled those items to the most comparable GAAP measures on our website, westernunion.com, under the Investor Relations section. All statements made by Western Union officers on this call are the property of the Western Union Company and subject to copyright protection. Other than the replay noted in our press release, Western Union has not authorized and disclaims responsibility for any recording, replay or distribution of any transcription of this call. 
I would now like turn the call over to Hikmet Ersek.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike, and good afternoon, everyone. Overall, we're pleased that our diversified global business and strategic initiatives enabled us to deliver another solid earnings performance in the third quarter. And we accomplished this, while mitigating
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike, and good afternoon, everyone. Overall, we're pleased that our diversified global business and strategic initiatives enabled us to deliver another solid earnings performance in the third quarter. And we accomplished this, while mitigating currency headwinds and market challenges in some international markets. Our U.S. business remains strong. And westernunion.com money transfer accelerated nicely, increasing 28% in constant currency. This growth help us balance all related softness in many of the Middle East and African countries. 
We delivered good margins, coming in at over 20% despite negative impacts from currency and a legal matter accrual, and we continue to generate strong cash flow and return significant funds to our shareholders. 
We are on track to deliver on our full year earnings outlook and are affirming our earnings per share range of $1.60 to $1.70. Total revenue in the quarter increased 2% on a constant-currency basis with the consumer money transfer business increasing 1%. Within money transfer, the U.S. business was strong across-the-board with good growth from both outbound and domestic money transfer. Our U.S. to Mexico business continues to shine and has now outpaced market growth for principal and transactions in each quarter for the past 3 years. In addition, we recently greatly expanded distribution in Mexico, nearly doubling our network. This was driven by the activation of our transfers, services at OXO, which is Mexico's largest convenience store geographically with 14,000 locations. With this new service, customers can stage transactions on the form in advance or through dedicated forms and digital kiosk in the stores, and then receive their funds at the counter. 
Turning to westernunion.com. This quarter's revenue increase is impressive, given the larger size of our digital business relative to competitors. We continue to see tremendous growth from the mobile app and the westernunion.com business was particularly strong in the U.S. market. We also continued to expand our digital assets, rolling out mobile apps in Canada and additional countries in Europe, giving us 16 transactional mobile apps in the market among our 37 westernunion.com countries. In addition, in the U.S. and the U.K., we have added a new omnichannel feature to our mobile apps. The customers can now fund same transactions from mobile apps via cards, accounts and also cash. This new feature allows consumers to start transactions on their smartphones and then pay with cash at agent locations, adding convenience and reduced time for in-store transactions. 
As I mentioned earlier, remittence flows from oil producing countries had been affected by the low oil price environment. While this is not a new factor, we did see softening in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, key markets in the Gulf that had largely maintained growth trends until the middle of the year.
Overall, the C2C pricing and competitive environment remains quite stable, as we had not seen significant changes in the marketplace. While there were some announcement recently concerning price changes for competitive services in limited areas, we don't anticipate this having significant impact on our business. 
We are very well positioned in the U.S. to Mexico corridor with our 50,000 agent locations in the U.S. and 26,000 in Mexico and a very competitive fee of $8 on sends up to $1,000.
In the U.S. domestic money transfer market, all the certain competitors are lowering fees on very high principal transfer, this is a small piece of our business to date. To put this in perspective, U.S. domestic money transfers over $1,000 represent less than 1% of company revenue. 
So overall, we are competitive with our current C2C product and pricing strategy, and for the new feature, we do not anticipate major companywide pricing adjustments. 
Turning to our -- to the other segments. The consumer bill payment business again delivered double-digit constant currency growth in the quarter, while Business Solutions was flat. Although Business Solutions had good growth from its payments product, especially verticals such as serving clients in the education sector, reductions in customers hedging activities, negatively impacted results. Strategically, we continue to advance our EDGE digital platform for importers and exporters. We have enabled thousands of business clients for use of the platform, which recently won payments innovation award in London. 
Overall, we remain on track to deliver our earnings outlook even with the many challenges we have faced this year. Our strong financial position has allowed us to continue investing in our platforms including advancements in our digital, technology and compliance assets and programs. And we are intent on further expanding our capabilities and network of digital and physical touch points. These include agent locations, mobile, online, account and kiosk, both direct and through our agent partners, as we leverage our platforms to offer consumers and businesses freedom of choice in how and when they want to move money across border.
We will talk more about our long-term strategies in the coming months. But right now, I want to turn the call over to Raj to discuss the third quarter results in more detail.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Hikmet. Third quarter reported revenues of $1.4 billion, declined 2% or increased 2% on a constant-currency basis compared to the prior-year period. The impact of currency translation, net of hedge benefits reduced third quarter revenue by appr
componenttext:
Thank you, Hikmet. Third quarter reported revenues of $1.4 billion, declined 2% or increased 2% on a constant-currency basis compared to the prior-year period. The impact of currency translation, net of hedge benefits reduced third quarter revenue by approximately $52 million compared to the prior year. In the Consumer-to-Consumer segment, revenues declined 1% in the quarter or increased 1% constant currency, while transactions grew 2%. C2C constant currency revenue benefited from strong growth in westernunion.com, while regional growth was led by North America and Latin America. However, softness from the oil-producing countries continue to negatively impact the Middle East and Africa and part of the Asia-Pacific region. Total C2C cross-border principal declined 3% or 2% on a constant-currency basis, while principal per transaction declined 5% or 4% in constant currency terms. The spread between the C2C transaction growth and the revenue decline in the quarter was approximately 3 percentage points, including a negative 2% impact in currency. Mix had a negative impact of approximately 2% in the quarter and was affected by the principal per transaction decline, while pricing had a positive 1 -- impact of 1%. 
Turning to the regions. Consistent with prior quarters, I will be referring to constant currency movements, as I discuss individual country contributions to the regional results. North America continue to deliver strong results in the quarter -- in the third quarter. Revenue grew 6% or 7% on an constant currency basis, while transactions increased 7%. U.S. outbound sends to Mexico and Latin America drove the region's revenue growth. In Mexico, our business continued to grow faster than the market based on the latest Banco de Mxico principal and transaction data for the third quarter. Our U.S. domestic money transfer business also posted good results, as revenue increased 4% and transaction growth improved to 5%. 
In the Europe and CIS region, revenue declined 2% or increased 1% on a constant currency basis, while transactions increased 2%. Revenue growth was driven by Greece and the U.K., partially offset by declines in Turkey. As a reminder, Greece was impacted in the third quarter of last year by government imposed market restrictions on money transfers during the country's financial crisis. 
In the Middle East and Africa region, revenue declined 10% or 8% constant currency and transactions were down 9%. Low oil prices continue to affect the region's results in the quarter, with trends weakening since last quarter in Saudi Arabia, Angola and the UAE. 
In the Asia Pacific region, revenue was down 4% or 3% constant currency, while transactions decreased 5%. Receive markets in the region, including India, continue to be negatively impacted by lower remittances from the oil-producing countries. Revenue in the Latin America and Caribbean region grew 3% and increased 8% constant currency, while transactions grew 12%. Revenue growth in the region was largely driven by strong inbound business from the U.S. 
Included in the regional numbers discussed, westernunion.com C2C revenue growth accelerated to 26% in the quarter or 28% constant currency and represented 8% of total C2C revenue. Westernunion.com transactions increased 29%, while U.S. originated online transactions grew 33%. 
In the Consumer-to-Business segment, revenue declined 3% or increased 11% on a constant currency basis. Constant currency revenue was driven by the Argentina walk-in and U.S. electronic businesses, which is partially offset by declines in U.S. cash walk-ins. The depreciation of the Argentine peso continued to declined in the reported revenues. Business Solutions revenue declined 4%. On a constant-currency basis revenues were flat, as good growth in Europe was offset by reduced customer hedging activities, particularly in Australia and an Canada. 
Turning to margins and profitability. The consolidated operating margin was 20.2% in the quarter compared to 21.8% in the prior-year period. This quarter's operating margin was negatively impacted by 110 basis points from a $15 million accrual related to the previously disclosed FTC legal matter. This is an addition to the $15 million we accrued for this in the second quarter, as we have not reached an appropriate resolution with the FTC at this time.  Other negative impacts from the margin included foreign exchange, customer and funding mix in the electronic bill payments business and incremental technology expense, which were partially offset by lower compensation and depreciation and amortization expenses. 
Foreign exchange hedge gains in the quarter were $12 million compared to $21 million of gains in the third quarter of last year. We continue to expect approximately $45 million in hedge gains for the year. Based on recent rates and our current hedge position, we currently project about $15 million of gains for 2017. In total, currency negatively impacted operating profit by approximately $22 million in the quarter compared to the same period last year. 
Compliance expense has been steady and came in at 3.5% of revenue in the quarter. EBITDA margin was 25.0%, down from 27.1% in the prior year period, as a result of the same negative factors that affected operating margin. 
The tax rate of 9.6% benefited from a 160 basis point impact from the FTC accrual in -- compared to 12.5% in the third quarter of last year. We still expect a full year rate of approximately 12%. 
Earnings per share was $0.44 in the quarter, including a negative $0.02 impact for the additional FTC accrual and compared to $0.45 in the third quarter of last year. 
The C2C segment operating margin of 23.4% was down from 25.5% in the prior year, and was negatively affected by 140 basis points from the accrual. The C2C margin was also negatively impacted by foreign exchange and higher technology expense, which were partially offset by lower compensation-related costs. 
The Consumer-to-Business operating margin was 9.1% in the quarter compared to 16.4% in the prior year. The margin decline was primarily due to customer and funding mix in the U.S. electronic business. The mix impacts relate to the addition of an large new biller [ph] of lower margins and general increases in credit card usage as a funding option by consumers. 
Business Solutions operating profit was $3 million or a 3.5% margin compared to a loss of $3 million in the prior year period. The operating profit improvement was driven by lower depreciation and amortization expense, which relates to the write-down for a contract termination in the third quarter of last year. 
Depreciation and amortization for Business Solutions was approximately $30 million in the quarter compared to $20 million in the prior year. The Business Solutions EBITDA margin was 17.1%, which compared to 17.4% in the third quarter of last year. 
Turning to our cash flow and balance sheet. Cash flow from operating activities was $822 million year-to-date through September. Capital expenditures were $68 million in the quarter. At the end of the quarter, we had debt of $3.2 billion and cash of $1.3 billion, with approximately 50% of the cash held by United States entities. 
After the quarter, in October, we retired $1 billion in maturing notes, which had a coupon of 5.93%. We're funded this maturity by drawing down on a $575 million term loan facility, which carries interest rates of LIBOR plus 150. And through a combination of cash usage and commercial paper issuance. During the third quarter, we repaid -- paid $78 million in dividends and repurchased approximately 4 million shares for a total of $84 million. Our remaining authorization, which expires in December 2017, was $310 million at quarter end and the outstanding share count at the end of September was 485 million shares. 
Turning to our outlook for the full year. We are narrowing the revenue growth outlook, while affirming operating profit margin, the EPS range and operating cash flow. The updated revenue outlook for the year is an increase of approximately 3% constant currency, which should translate to a decrease of approximately 1% on a GAAP basis. Operating profit margin for the full year, remains approximately 20%, while EPS remains in a range of $1.60 to $1.70. We have been able to maintain the margin outlook despite the unanticipated $30 million of legal matter accruals during the year, due to favorability and other expenses. We continue to expect to generate $1 billion in cash flow from operating activities, and we now expect the $100 million of anticipated final tax payments related to the previously announced IRS agreements be paid in 2017. 
So to summarize, we delivered solid results for the quarter and remain on track with our full year earnings outlook. Our cash flow and balance sheet are strong and we continue to return significant funds to shareholders. 
Operator, we are now ready to take questions.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Jason Kupferberg of Jefferies.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Jason Kupferberg of Jefferies.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan Cary for Jason. Clearly low oil prices continue to be a headwind to results. Could we expect negative growth as kind of the new normal for the time being in the petro producing regions? Or is the impact less structural in these regions could
componenttext: This is Ryan Cary for Jason. Clearly low oil prices continue to be a headwind to results. Could we expect negative growth as kind of the new normal for the time being in the petro producing regions? Or is the impact less structural in these regions could recover relatively quickly with a rebounded in energy prices?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we did see some impact, which -- especially from the Middle East and Middle East related oil producing countries, that's the fact. But I will say overall being in 200 countries having that portfolio, that balances the strong U.S. growth, the
componenttext: Yes, I think we did see some impact, which -- especially from the Middle East and Middle East related oil producing countries, that's the fact. But I will say overall being in 200 countries having that portfolio, that balances the strong U.S. growth, the strong westernunion.com digital growth, accelerating the transactions and revenues is really great results. It has -- I would say, it takes time, right? If all these prices are higher, the jobs have to be created, the investments have to be done in Saudi Arabia or UAE and Middle East countries, that creates jobs. And if the people have jobs, they send money. But as you know, putting things in perspective, it's a good part of business, but not that big part of business and being in 200 countries helps us to have good results.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just follow up. How should we be thinking about the tax rate going forward? I believe, you call it expectations for kind of mid-teen tax rate over the next couple of years. But it seems like over the last 3 to 4, there's often been the initial
componenttext: Great. And just follow up. How should we be thinking about the tax rate going forward? I believe, you call it expectations for kind of mid-teen tax rate over the next couple of years. But it seems like over the last 3 to 4, there's often been the initial assumption before coming in a couple hundred basis points later. So is this the trend that we shouldn't expect to continue going forward or -- I mean, I'm trying to get a sense of how we should think about the tax rate, particularly, after kind of lighter than expected this quarter?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ryan, this is Raj. We still target a mid-teens tax rate and that's still what we expect for the next couple of years based on what we know today about tax loss and the current environment with our business. We've continue to benefit from some discree
componenttext: Yes. Ryan, this is Raj. We still target a mid-teens tax rate and that's still what we expect for the next couple of years based on what we know today about tax loss and the current environment with our business. We've continue to benefit from some discreet items that have helped us during the course of the year. In this quarter, for example, we obviously, we got a benefit from the larger accrual in the U.S., which helps to -- helps the mix on the overall tax rate. We also have had some favorable resolutions to various outstanding tax matters with various governments around the world. And so that continues to help us, and we're going to continue to try to do that as much as we can. Putting aside the discreet items, we're probably in that mid-teens rate, which is what we fully expected when we came into this year. But we're doing a good job in trying to manage things as best as we can on the tax side and that continues to be our goal.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from Jim Schneider of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And the next question will come from Jim Schneider of Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if can maybe talk a little bit about the acceleration in the westernunion.com business, kind of the -- some of the geographies it might have been underlying that, and I guess, if you can kind of look forward, talk about some of the factors
componenttext: I was wondering if can maybe talk a little bit about the acceleration in the westernunion.com business, kind of the -- some of the geographies it might have been underlying that, and I guess, if you can kind of look forward, talk about some of the factors that might help you close the gap between transaction growth and revenue growth?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, this is -- there is good news, right? This is fantastic news our acceleration of .com [ph] especially given the size of how big our westernunion.com business already is, 8% of our total revenue and accelerating about 28% and transaction about 29%. Th
componenttext: Jim, this is -- there is good news, right? This is fantastic news our acceleration of .com [ph] especially given the size of how big our westernunion.com business already is, 8% of our total revenue and accelerating about 28% and transaction about 29%. The growth comes from both sides, expansion geographically, and -- but also very strong U.S. business, which have been for many, many years here. So customers are returning using us, they love the app, the westernunion.com app. Our transactions in the U.S. are growing by 33%. And that's amazing, and we are really gaining their market share and getting new customers. Still the customers are new. 80% of the customers using westernunion.com digital environment, are new to Western Union. They didn't use last 12 months records, Raj, right? They didn't use us the last 12 months.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes..
componenttext: Yes..

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And its a great story, and then now we are in 16 countries.
componenttext: And its a great story, and then now we are in 16 countries.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: 37 [ph] countries.
componenttext: 37 [ph] countries.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the Westernunion.com, 16 countries on mobile app. And we recently also launched new features in Canada and U.K., where you can really stage the transaction if somebody doesn't want to use bank account or credit card, they can go to a location and stage
componenttext: In the Westernunion.com, 16 countries on mobile app. And we recently also launched new features in Canada and U.K., where you can really stage the transaction if somebody doesn't want to use bank account or credit card, they can go to a location and stage a transaction, pay in -- at a location. So these things are definitely the [ph] multi-product and multi-channel environments helping. The other thing is also, what the competitors don't have and that's why they're not growing that fast is that, we are in 200 countries. We can drop money in 16,000 corridors with 1 app. From Canada, you can send money to 200 countries. From U.K., can send money to 200 countries. From 37 countries, electronic to digital, you can send money, that's the growth part. So we are very pleased with our digital growth and that's going to continue, our investment is going to continue. My expectations will be -- I'm very motivated with that.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good to hear. And then maybe just as a quick follow-up. There's been a lot of headlines around the Walmart U.S. to Mexico kind of pricing structures that they recently published. Can you maybe talk about whether you expect any potential knock-on ef
componenttext: That's good to hear. And then maybe just as a quick follow-up. There's been a lot of headlines around the Walmart U.S. to Mexico kind of pricing structures that they recently published. Can you maybe talk about whether you expect any potential knock-on effect relative to the rest of the market, and I know Walmart is pretty small, but still, I guess, there is a speculation about whether that could have a broader market effect? Or where you think is this going to be confined to simply Walmart?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I wouldn't say Walmart is small, in particular, but in this business, it is small. We have 50,000 locations in the U.S. and 26,000 locations in Mexico. And our pricing has been very compatible also, $8 for up to $1,000. And the fact speaks its langu
componenttext: Well, I wouldn't say Walmart is small, in particular, but in this business, it is small. We have 50,000 locations in the U.S. and 26,000 locations in Mexico. And our pricing has been very compatible also, $8 for up to $1,000. And the fact speaks its language. We've been gaining market share for 3 years every quarter and these facts are from Banco de Mxico facts. So the distribution, the product positioning, the pricing, the brand, the compliance programs, all these platforms help us to be gaining market share. So we will always do pricing actions corridor-by-corridor. We will look at that. But I feel quite competitive with our pricing, and I see the pricing is very stable, and we're going to continue hopefully gaining market share in this very important corridor for us.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Tien-tsin Huang of JP Morgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Tien-tsin Huang of JP Morgan.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the pricing front, I think, I heard plus 1%, so where are you being more opportunistic? Does it change more on the FX side or transaction-based side, just any more color there would be good?
componenttext: Just on the pricing front, I think, I heard plus 1%, so where are you being more opportunistic? Does it change more on the FX side or transaction-based side, just any more color there would be good?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Tien-tsin, you know, our business so very well. We are in -- as you know, we are in so many countries, so many bands, so many different things. I would say that generally we still have 15% to 20% premium on average, globally. Our price has been not
componenttext: Well, Tien-tsin, you know, our business so very well. We are in -- as you know, we are in so many countries, so many bands, so many different things. I would say that generally we still have 15% to 20% premium on average, globally. Our price has been not affected and we will -- the increases comes on FX, most of the time FX increases, but in some corridors also in the fee, and some corridors, we decreased, actually, also prices. And as you know, being in so many corridors, being in so many countries, its a portfolio management. We feel comfortable by gaining market share also in some corridors increasing the FX rates that helped also and its mix, basically, it's the mix, it's not a big increase. Obviously, it's really the mix that impacts our 1%. Raj, is that true?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think you answered it well. We -- there was some volatility as we -- as the Brexit activity took place at the end of the second quarter, and that we've put some different spreads in place, so that helped us, Tien-tsin, overall in the business
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think you answered it well. We -- there was some volatility as we -- as the Brexit activity took place at the end of the second quarter, and that we've put some different spreads in place, so that helped us, Tien-tsin, overall in the business from a pricing standpoint. But we do increases and decreases on an ongoing basis throughout our business.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's good to know. Just on the Business Solutions side, any change in how we should look at that in the fourth quarter and maybe into 2017? I know that FX is all over the place and sort of macro trade is all over the place, I don't know if this ha
componenttext: Okay. That's good to know. Just on the Business Solutions side, any change in how we should look at that in the fourth quarter and maybe into 2017? I know that FX is all over the place and sort of macro trade is all over the place, I don't know if this has been a share change as well, but any updated insight on Business Solutions?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On Business Solutions, if you look at the Business Solutions, we're very pleased with our payment sector, the verticals where the students pay as a payments. On the hedging side, volatility always helps, right? The global trade has been sloth [ph] e
componenttext: Sure. On Business Solutions, if you look at the Business Solutions, we're very pleased with our payment sector, the verticals where the students pay as a payments. On the hedging side, volatility always helps, right? The global trade has been sloth [ph] engine, that's been many affected and especially in the countries we are operating has been slow. Seeing that, we're still very important for us, that's why we invest in the EDGE digital platform. We have thousands of exporters, importers registered there. They are trading in this platform. And that will be definitely helping on long-term on our numbers. But short-term volatility will help us and global trade will help us.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we've a question from Bryan Keane of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Next, we've a question from Bryan Keane of Deutsche Bank.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask about the guidance. It looks like you guys narrowed the revenue guidance range of 3% constant currency, and if I believe, the first half of the year was 3% constant currency, third quarter was 2% constant currency. So I'm just trying to
componenttext: Just wanted to ask about the guidance. It looks like you guys narrowed the revenue guidance range of 3% constant currency, and if I believe, the first half of the year was 3% constant currency, third quarter was 2% constant currency. So I'm just trying to figure, are you guys expecting a little bit of a pick up in constant currency revenue growth in 4Q to round at 3%?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We just -- we said approximately 3%, Bryan. So it obviously can be a range of outcomes for the fourth quarter that still give us 3% for the full year, but that's approximately 3% for the full year. That's about where we've been running throughout the firs
componenttext: We just -- we said approximately 3%, Bryan. So it obviously can be a range of outcomes for the fourth quarter that still give us 3% for the full year, but that's approximately 3% for the full year. That's about where we've been running throughout the first 3 quarters of the year and that's about where we expect for the full year.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you've narrowed kind of the revenue range, but didn't narrow the earnings per share. And obviously, there's still a $0.10 range there, which is a wide variety of outcomes for the fourth quarter. Can you just talk a little bit about what wou
componenttext: Okay. And then you've narrowed kind of the revenue range, but didn't narrow the earnings per share. And obviously, there's still a $0.10 range there, which is a wide variety of outcomes for the fourth quarter. Can you just talk a little bit about what would get you to the low-end of the range and to the high-end of the range and maybe where you guys feel more comfortable?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say we feel comfortable with the range as it is. We didn't really change the range primarily because we've also taken into account the $30 million of additional legal accruals that we've had now through the first -- through the last couple of quar
componenttext: I would say we feel comfortable with the range as it is. We didn't really change the range primarily because we've also taken into account the $30 million of additional legal accruals that we've had now through the first -- through the last couple of quarters. For us, the outlook really hasn't changed a lot. We continue to see the business trending the way it has been. We reiterated margins at 20%. We also have the same cash flow outlook. And our EPS range, we just didn't change it because of the -- what we've -- because of legal items. But you can see that through the first 3 quarters and even the third quarter, we got an EPS of $0.44, which is very much in line with our expectations, and we feel good about the full year outlook.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Raj, we talked about that we would -- we wouldn't have the $30 million debt [ph], that outlook would be different. It will be in the higher-end.
componenttext: I think, Raj, we talked about that we would -- we wouldn't have the $30 million debt [ph], that outlook would be different. It will be in the higher-end.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We would have probably updated the outlook had we not had the $30 million that we've taken into account.
componenttext: Yes. We would have probably updated the outlook had we not had the $30 million that we've taken into account.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. But no real one-time items to think about on a comparable basis from 4Q last year?
componenttext: Okay. But no real one-time items to think about on a comparable basis from 4Q last year?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, no. Not really. If we have any one-time type items or the things that we might do to address the cost structure, we will certainly tell you about those once we finish out the year. But nothing that we can discuss at this stage. We're always looking fo
componenttext: No, no. Not really. If we have any one-time type items or the things that we might do to address the cost structure, we will certainly tell you about those once we finish out the year. But nothing that we can discuss at this stage. We're always looking for cost efficiencies and opportunities for the business, but nothing to call at, at this stage.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we have a question from Darrin Peller of Barclays.
componenttext: And next, we have a question from Darrin Peller of Barclays.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just -- just on the quick follow-up around the margin. I mean it does seem like there was some items in there and obviously you've been able to maintain it relatively stable despite that. So -- I mean, I guess, can you just maybe rewind and give us a se
componenttext: I just -- just on the quick follow-up around the margin. I mean it does seem like there was some items in there and obviously you've been able to maintain it relatively stable despite that. So -- I mean, I guess, can you just maybe rewind and give us a sense of what you see as the operating leverage opportunity? In other words, if we were to show 3% growth once again in 2017, I mean, is there any reason to see -- to expect to not be able to expect some margin expansion on that?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Darrin, I can't talk about 2017 margins. But the reason we've been able to maintain the margin this year at around 20% is we have managed our expenses quite tightly, even though we've taken into account an additional $30 million of legal costs, we're
componenttext: Yes. Darrin, I can't talk about 2017 margins. But the reason we've been able to maintain the margin this year at around 20% is we have managed our expenses quite tightly, even though we've taken into account an additional $30 million of legal costs, we're been able to do that. For us, obviously, we need to get good revenue growth to drive better profitability. But then you have to look at our other cost items that will have an impact, obviously, like our commissions which have been flat the last couple of years. Our compliance costs have also been relatively stable at that 3.5% to 4% range. And then as I mentioned just earlier, we'll continue to look for cost optimization opportunities. So all of those things will have an impact, and yes, we'll more color for you on those things as we finish out the year. But the margin this year, we're pleased with the 20% operating margin outlook even in the face of some of these other things that we've had to deal with.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And prices are stable from top line that helps also.
componenttext: And prices are stable from top line that helps also.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And also just generally I would say that, the company [indiscernible] operating in a much better way, more efficient way, despite all the challenges, global challenges, I think, we found a way to operate very effectively.
componenttext: And also just generally I would say that, the company [indiscernible] operating in a much better way, more efficient way, despite all the challenges, global challenges, I think, we found a way to operate very effectively.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick follow up on the guidance question. I mean, understand you're saying it's just 3% and there is a lot of outcomes that can get there. But I guess, I'm just trying to figure out what may have been in your expectations beforehand could
componenttext: Okay. And just a quick follow up on the guidance question. I mean, understand you're saying it's just 3% and there is a lot of outcomes that can get there. But I guess, I'm just trying to figure out what may have been in your expectations beforehand could be low to mid-single digit top line versus now 3%? What changed I guess, and again, we understand it's not a massive move from one to the other, but anything would be helpful?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've been running at 3% for the first half of the year on a constant-currency basis. And we still had 6 months left in the year when we maintained our outlook last quarter, low- to-mid-digits. But as we've seen a tick down in the business given the
componenttext: Well, we've been running at 3% for the first half of the year on a constant-currency basis. And we still had 6 months left in the year when we maintained our outlook last quarter, low- to-mid-digits. But as we've seen a tick down in the business given the oil-related markets, we're more comfortable with the 3% revenue growth outlook because of the performance that we had in the third quarter. And it's really the Middle East and the oil-related markets that have shown a tick down, because we're continuing to get very strong growth in the other markets like the U.S., Alpine to Mexico to Latin America, the domestic business, the digital business obviously. And so those trends haven't really changed. We've seen just a tick down in the Middle East and Africa business, which is impacting APAC, as well.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Just last quick one. I mean on the mobile side, last quarter, I know you guys had a bit of spread between the revenue growth rate and the transaction growth. It actually looked like [indiscernible] to the point mentioned earlier, by someon
componenttext: That's helpful. Just last quick one. I mean on the mobile side, last quarter, I know you guys had a bit of spread between the revenue growth rate and the transaction growth. It actually looked like [indiscernible] to the point mentioned earlier, by someone, it definitely improved not only say, I know you commented on mobile being a driver of the acceleration on wu.com, but can you help us understand why the revenue per transaction would have improved so much given how much is mobile?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're continuing to see very strong growth in the mobile channel for wu.com and we're pleased with that, so that hasn't changed from before. We -- as we mentioned before, we do pricing optimization throughout our business including our various channe
componenttext: Yes. We're continuing to see very strong growth in the mobile channel for wu.com and we're pleased with that, so that hasn't changed from before. We -- as we mentioned before, we do pricing optimization throughout our business including our various channels, and we did increase some spreads in the  .com business. But our overall pricing in the .com business is very market competitive when you look at the rest of the competition. So we're just really aligning and maximizing the opportunity there. And we're getting very consistent growth with transaction growth, 29% transaction growth and 28% constant revenue growth. So it's a pretty consistent picture and it's very consistent with what we had expected coming into the second half of this year.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Ashwin Shirvaikar of Citi.
componenttext: The next question comes from Ashwin Shirvaikar of Citi.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I have a question about that legal accrual. I think presentation did mention that there was an offset compensation in DNA, if you could size that, that would be helpful? And then as we kind of all start thinking about next year's model, what are the he
componenttext: So I have a question about that legal accrual. I think presentation did mention that there was an offset compensation in DNA, if you could size that, that would be helpful? And then as we kind of all start thinking about next year's model, what are the headwinds and tailwinds, is it fair to assume that on the headwind side there's probably about $0.0.5 of tax rate, but on the tailwind side, you probably have the hedge [ph] loss that you don't have any more, can you help kind of with the timing of that?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ashwin, let me try to answer your questions. The -- in the SG&A line, as you mentioned, we had the FTC legal accrual for $15 million, that's the size of it. The -- there were some offsets with lower compensation and lower DNA. And SG&A, as a percenta
componenttext: Yes. Ashwin, let me try to answer your questions. The -- in the SG&A line, as you mentioned, we had the FTC legal accrual for $15 million, that's the size of it. The -- there were some offsets with lower compensation and lower DNA. And SG&A, as a percentage of revenues, was up just a little bit from the last year. So I'd just like you do the math, but there was a slight...

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: The DNA, as we mentioned, the Business Solutions that was a one-time charge we took a year ago, and we closed about $7 million difference in the Business Solutions DNA.
componenttext: The DNA, as we mentioned, the Business Solutions that was a one-time charge we took a year ago, and we closed about $7 million difference in the Business Solutions DNA.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the rest of it is just the comp. As you look at next year, I can't really go into specifics, but there are a number of different factors to consider all the things that I mentioned in previous question around revenue growth as well as the various cost
componenttext: And the rest of it is just the comp. As you look at next year, I can't really go into specifics, but there are a number of different factors to consider all the things that I mentioned in previous question around revenue growth as well as the various cost items, but tax will certainly be a consideration. Putting aside any discrete items as I mentioned, earlier for the next couple of years, we would probably be in the mid-teens area for tax rate. But as I also mentioned, we're always trying to look for opportunities to optimize our tax rate. We will have some interest savings as we go into next year because of the refinancing that we just did. Ultimate amount of interest rates will depend on our debt level and then we also have a refinancing to make sure that we have to do, so there be some negative carry related to that. And then we also have the hedge gains that will -- if rates stay exactly where they're today, then we'll have less in hedge gain. So all of those things will have to come together and how we ultimately look from a profit standpoint.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So okay -- I guess, the follow-up question just a clarification. The -- in your presentation again, in that C2C chart, where you provide the transaction to revenue bridge, if there's other mix? And I've might have missed what the explanation for t
componenttext: Got it. So okay -- I guess, the follow-up question just a clarification. The -- in your presentation again, in that C2C chart, where you provide the transaction to revenue bridge, if there's other mix? And I've might have missed what the explanation for the other mix was?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it's very simply, we had lower growth or softness in higher RPT markets. Our principal per transaction was down by about 4% on a constant-currency basis and that's largely being driven by Europe and certain parts of the Middle East. So it's r
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it's very simply, we had lower growth or softness in higher RPT markets. Our principal per transaction was down by about 4% on a constant-currency basis and that's largely being driven by Europe and certain parts of the Middle East. So it's really the mix impact that's showing up in that negative 2%.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from Kartik Mehta of Northcoast Research.
componenttext: And the next question will come from Kartik Mehta of Northcoast Research.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to -- the wu.com as you talked about the transactions and revenue are coming in closer and seems as though you've able to manage your spread there. Is that a result of you pricing differently? Or is that the result of the competition being less a
componenttext: I wanted to -- the wu.com as you talked about the transactions and revenue are coming in closer and seems as though you've able to manage your spread there. Is that a result of you pricing differently? Or is that the result of the competition being less aggressive and allowing you to manage pricing better?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: While I can't speak in name of competition what's their issues is. Their issues, I guess, mostly the can't expand through globally and they don't have the power to expand globally and they don't have -- they can't drop money to the billing accounts we hav
componenttext: While I can't speak in name of competition what's their issues is. Their issues, I guess, mostly the can't expand through globally and they don't have the power to expand globally and they don't have -- they can't drop money to the billing accounts we have and they can't drop money to 500,000 locations and everything, right? I think the strong growth is 2 things, Karthik. First one is, the customers are coming back, who use once mobile, they love it, they stay there, they coming back. We see that very good. And that's the U.S. growth besides getting more customers, we are really having returning customers and the team is doing good job on that communicating with them online with via mobile, really motive -- having loyalty programs, which is great getting back. The second thing is the geographical expansion. Expansion in Canada, expansion in U.K. with new devices, but also in Europe and now, we are starting to expand that also, you'll see recent announcement, coming announcement in other countries in Asia, in other parts of Europe and Middle East, we're going to expand our online and our .com activities and mobile activities. And it's a good business to expand. Raj?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add, Karthik, that 1 unique feature that we have that most other competition does not have is cash payout. We initiate transactions online, but we have a vast retail network that really sets us apart from other competitors.
componenttext: I would just add, Karthik, that 1 unique feature that we have that most other competition does not have is cash payout. We initiate transactions online, but we have a vast retail network that really sets us apart from other competitors.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. If that linked is definitely the compliance programs then, you have to have a license to operate in a country and that's not easy to get it. And we've been there for many, many years, and we are really building our digital transformation. The digital
componenttext: Yes. If that linked is definitely the compliance programs then, you have to have a license to operate in a country and that's not easy to get it. And we've been there for many, many years, and we are really building our digital transformation. The digital transformation is happening build our fundamentals and other the competition has probably to get there first.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just an overall pricing, obviously, you had a positive impact. Anything that you see on the horizon that changes that? Or do you think this environment you'll be able to kind of sustain the pricing levels that they're, right now?
componenttext: And then just an overall pricing, obviously, you had a positive impact. Anything that you see on the horizon that changes that? Or do you think this environment you'll be able to kind of sustain the pricing levels that they're, right now?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at the market, it's quite stable, right? I don't see any big noise out there. There has been some announcements done by the competition, but we feel we are pretty well positioned overall. We still have 15% to 20% premium globally. And we
componenttext: Well, if you look at the market, it's quite stable, right? I don't see any big noise out there. There has been some announcements done by the competition, but we feel we are pretty well positioned overall. We still have 15% to 20% premium globally. And we did -- we will continue the pricing actions, but it won't have a -- we're going to stay in our historical norm, and that will -- have been -- we feel comfortable on that for the near future. I don't see big changes.

componenttext: And then just last question, Raj. I just want to make sure I heard you correctly. You said, I know you don't want to give 2017 guidance, I understand that, but you're talking about some of the things that we should consider. On interest expense, did you say, you thought that would be headwind? Or did you not say that?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I did not say that. I said that interest expense would likely be lower next year given the refinancing we've done. Part of the refinancing was the term loan as I mentioned, in our comments, which is at LIBOR plus 150 basis points, which is lower obviously
componenttext: I did not say that. I said that interest expense would likely be lower next year given the refinancing we've done. Part of the refinancing was the term loan as I mentioned, in our comments, which is at LIBOR plus 150 basis points, which is lower obviously than the note that we just retired at 5.93% and the recent commercial [indiscernible]. So we'll get interest savings there, but it might be offset with some other components here that I also mentioned. And then we also have another refinancing to do next year of $500 million, which is at the end of the year, but we may refinance that earlier in the year, so there could be some negative carry as well associated with that.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Craig Maurer for Matt O'Neil. Just a broad-based question. You had stated in the prepared comments that you're comfortable with pricing where it is now. But should the oil economies not recover and the global economy remain suspect, do you have any o
componenttext: It's Craig Maurer for Matt O'Neil. Just a broad-based question. You had stated in the prepared comments that you're comfortable with pricing where it is now. But should the oil economies not recover and the global economy remain suspect, do you have any other pricing leverage other than risk that you could use to reverse the decline in transaction growth?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at our business, I mean, there's a global challenge, it's for all, right? It's not a competitive challenge, it's for -- affects everyone. I think that in the markets where we are, we feel very competitive with pricing. As I said earlier,
componenttext: Well, if you look at our business, I mean, there's a global challenge, it's for all, right? It's not a competitive challenge, it's for -- affects everyone. I think that in the markets where we are, we feel very competitive with pricing. As I said earlier, we will always do pricing. That's the beauty of having this portfolio. And we didn't do the 16,000 corridors. We have different customer used cases. We've different bands receiving sender FX and fees, so we can do that. We're going to continue to do that and I feel comfortable where it is. I think it was more a noise up there with the announcements. And currently, near future, what I hear from my market leaders, they feel comfortable. What I hear from our digital leaders, they feel very comfortable. That's -- and we are growing with our numbers, 28%, digital growth is impressive, a very stable, a very resilient retail business. And for the near future, I don't see, I can't predict the future -- long-term future, but I feel comfortable where the business is.

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. So just thinking ahead, I know you don't want to comment on '17, but I mean your positive comment seems to be slanted towards some level of a recovery in those markets. So I suppose as we think out to the guide, did you not get a -- did y
componenttext: Okay, all right. So just thinking ahead, I know you don't want to comment on '17, but I mean your positive comment seems to be slanted towards some level of a recovery in those markets. So I suppose as we think out to the guide, did you not get a -- did you not get any improvement in the oil economies, which probably expect the continuation of trends seen in the quarter?

headline: The Western Union Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I can't predict the economy, the oil prices, right? I can't predict the global economy. And that's something I'm always cautious. And I said, beginning of the year, '16 is cautious and today it's where I am still staying cautious, right? But the bea
componenttext: Well, I can't predict the economy, the oil prices, right? I can't predict the global economy. And that's something I'm always cautious. And I said, beginning of the year, '16 is cautious and today it's where I am still staying cautious, right? But the beauty of our business, if you look at our total business, not only U.S., worldwide, we've been always up and downs. And currently in the U.S., we are doing a good job outbound and intra business doing very well, digital doing very well. Parts of like U.K., although, there's Brexit talk and everything, U.K. business is doing very well. Our Australia business is doing well. We do have impact in the Saudi Arabia and UAE, where they send money to mostly to South Asia. This corridor has been impacted. And that's why some parts of -- like India corridors has been a slower growth because Saudi Arabia send and UAE send has been slower.
